HEADLINE: The Cost of Staying Out of Jail

BYLINE: By Kirsten D. Levingston. 
Kirsten D. Levingston is the director of the criminal justice program at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law.

 BODY:
WHEN he released his budget in January, Gov. George Pataki boasted that New York was the safest large state in the nation. He also proposed programs to help people leaving prison ''become productive, law-abiding citizens.'' Indeed, the governor rightly links a convict's reintegration into society with public safety. 
 But nestled in Governor Pataki's budget is a proposal that would make it far harder for people on probation -- those sentenced to a period of correctional supervision in their communities instead of in prison -- to rejoin those communities and enter the economic mainstream. The governor's plan authorizes every county and the City of New York to pile thousands of dollars in fees and fines on probationers. 
These new fees would pay for the cost of things like electronic monitoring, drug testing and DNA databank submissions, adding more than $3,500 to an already daunting array of financial punishments that include the costs of, among other things, a crime-victim assistance fee and a cash bail fee that people convicted of crimes may face. Moreover, probationers must pay off these monetary obligations before they can emerge from probation supervision. 
 Today, these fees and fines serve varied purposes. Some are intended to punish or make a victim whole. Others are assessed to offset administrative costs, like probation supervision expenses. Still others raise funds that go into government coffers for general use, like the DNA databank fee. 
 Governor Pataki's proposal has nothing to do with compensating victims. It simply allows local governments to offset the cost of supervising people on probation, essentially creating a probationer's tax. Twenty years ago, in weighing the pros and cons of probation fees, the National Institute of Corrections, an agency within the United States Department of Justice, said that fees like these ''represent double taxation: the assessment of a user fee is, in reality, payment for services already supported by general taxes paid by probationers.''
 Strangely enough, many of these fees and fines may be far harsher than the original punishment. Most probationers are not convicted of felonies, but are guilty of misdemeanors, petty offenses not punished by long jail time. Yet failure to pay fees and fines can land them in jail even if their actual offenses did not. While this sounds like something out of a Dickens novel, examples of this are multiplying as fees and fines are increased across the country.
 To be sure, financial punishment sounds like a relatively painless way of being tough on crime. After all, if given the choice between a financial penalty or time in prison, most of us would gladly reach into our pockets. And the state avoids the cost of actually locking someone up when fees and fines replace cell time. But this solution is merely the latest example of a policy that erects barriers to successful reintegration into society for those convicted of crimes. 
 Like the rest of us, many people on probation face multiple financial obligations. They are supporting families, paying rent or mortgages and making sure the lights stay on. Unlike the general population, however, some 80 percent of defendants in the justice system are indigent, according to the Center for Community Alternatives, a nonprofit organization that closely monitors these fees in New York. 
 If a $3,500 debt matters to you, imagine what it would mean to a poor person with a criminal conviction who is struggling to get a decent job and either return to the mainstream economy or enter it for the first time. The mere appearance of a justice system-imposed obligation on someone's credit history can flag a criminal history even if a court has sealed or erased a person's criminal record, or if the conviction information is years old, making it even more difficult to land a job.
 According to the National Institute of Corrections, ''The added stress caused by inability to pay may cause probationers to miss appointments, thus negating any positive effect of supervision and sometimes resulting in revocation for failure to comply with the conditions of probation.'' 
 Acknowledging that fees and fines can be a ball and chain that hold people back, the Council of State Governments, a nonprofit good governance group, has urged states to strike an ''especially careful balance between achieving reparative justice (for the victim or community), meeting the needs of the released person's family and creating a manageable, if difficult, obligation for the individual.'' 
 Governor Pataki's proposal does not strike that balance. It would be folly to proclaim our devotion to re-entry of prisoners into society with the one hand, while imposing financial burdens with the other that will make it harder for them to get jobs and stay out of jail.

HEADLINE: A Paint Job? Yes, and a Painting Job, Too

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BRIGHTEN school walls and brighten students' prospects.
 It's all part of the same palette, according to a group that runs a program in which students in New York City's middle and high schools volunteer to paint the halls, cafeterias and other common areas of older schools in vibrant tones of yellow, green, blue, red and orange.
The nonprofit group, Publicolor, says that besides creating a more energizing learning environment than the institutional grays and tans that the brighter colors usually replace, the project gets many indifferent or misbehaving students engaged with their schools. And it says the project also introduces participants to the habits and discipline they will need in the world of work. 
 For those who advance in the program, the painting tasks are combined with academic tutoring and after-school workshops on career possibilities and, for those interested, on choosing and applying to colleges. Some have received scholarships from Publicolor.
 There can also be a financial reward, which is important because most of the boys and girls in the program are from poor or working-class families. While those on the program's beginner level, who can be as young as 11, are not paid for their work, those on the advanced level, who must be at least 13, can qualify for stipends of $20 to $30 a week. A small number of high school students are deemed semiprofessionals, because of their skills, and earn $20 to $50 for each day's work.
 Participating schools are chosen from among those whose principals request inclusion, and from recommendations from others. A principal's agreement is required for work in a school, said Kelcey Kintner, a member of Publicolor's staff. ''We look to choose schools that are failing academically, have big dropout rates and are depressing visually,'' she said.
 A recent late-afternoon visit to Intermediate School 291 in Bushwick, Brooklyn, one of three schools currently being painted, provided a snapshot of Publicolor's operation.
 Recently, state education officials added the school to a list of those at risk of being shut down because of low academic performance.
 Ten students from the school, including Diontre Cornish, 11, had stayed after classes to paint doors on the second floor a rich blue. Three older students, including Jeremiah Butler, 18, had come from other schools to paint and help guide younger participants.
 ''Painting is a way to interact with other children,'' said Diontre, a sixth grader.
 Jeremiah, a senior at Paul Robeson High School in Brooklyn, said he had found Publicolor's business workshops valuable. ''I want to be an entrepreneur,'' he said, speaking of owning a clothing or record store one day.
 Publicolor was founded in 1996 by Ruth Lande Shuman, an industrial designer who has studied the psychological effects of color. ''I wanted to try to use my talent to help engage disaffected students in their education, so they would not drop out of school,'' she said recently. 
 More than 5,000 students have taken part in the 10-year-old program, most at their own schools, Ms. Kintner said, adding that each project takes several months to a year. About 450 students have moved to the advanced level, which involves painting schools other than their own and homeless shelters, police stations and other city buildings. The program has steadily expanded, with up to nine schools being painted annually in the last few years, and 74 altogether, Ms. Kintner said. 
 Ms. Shuman said she did not know whether dropout rates had declined at schools after they had been painted, but a study of the question is planned. Nor does she know if any former participants had taken up painting as a livelihood.
 The work is done after school and on Saturdays, and business and professional people who support the program often join the students on that day. Publicolor, whose budget this year is $2.1 million, operates largely on donations from businesses, foundations and private contributors.
 Carmen Farina, the city's deputy chancellor for teaching and learning, said she was a ''big fan'' of the program. ''Any organization that encourages kids to stay in school till 6, 7 at night and brings them in on weekends,'' she said, ''is instilling the values we desire.''

HEADLINE: That Sound You Hear? The Market Coming Down to Earth

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO; Reporting for this article was contributed by Ford Fessenden, as well as by Kathleen McGrory in Westchester, Faiza Akhtar and Sophia Chang on Long Island, John Koblin and Nate Schweber in New Jersey and Alejandro Lazo and Avi Salzman in Connecticut.

 BODY:
AS clusters of open-house balloons bob across the suburbs of the metropolitan area, from the New Englandy enclaves of Fairfield County, Conn., to the salt-sprayed boroughs of the Jersey Shore, the question remains: whither the housing market?
 Everyone, it seems, has an answer, and those answers can be strangely contradictory and accurate at the same time. If inventory is your gauge, the market is slackening. If prices are your prism, it's still going strong.
But in interviews with more than two dozen real estate agents, buyers, sellers and economists, the consensus is that the housing market in the region remains remarkably buoyant but is coming down to earth. Prices are still in the clouds, but inventory is expanding and bidding wars, once commonplace, are increasingly rare.
 If the boom is over, there is no bust in sight. ''It's turning,'' said Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business organization. ''It's neither a buyer's nor a seller's market.'' 
 Buyers say they no longer feel pressured to make an offer the moment they step over the doorsill. (There are even isolated reports of some sellers getting lowball offers.) Brokers, meanwhile, are lecturing sellers to be more realistic about prices, and sellers are working harder to spruce up their homes.
 ''A few years ago, sellers were not making their beds and leaving dishes in the sink, and buyers were still coming and buying,'' said Cindy DeRose, a sales agent for Hudson Shores Realtors in Irvington, N.Y. ''It is still a healthy market. But it has cooled down enough that sellers just have to do a little more work, frankly.''
 Of course, the real estate market in the New York City suburbs has long had its ups and downs. But over time, houses there have proved to be extraordinary investments because people want to be close to the city while enjoying the relative safety and good public schools the suburbs tend to offer.
 Though the pattern of contradiction in the current market seems fairly consistent from state to state, there are differences from one community to the next, with some towns appearing almost impervious to any downturn, at least for now. 
 Frank Anthony, a sales associate for Coldwell Banker in Mendham, called the current market ''town sensitive.'' He compared a Cape Cod in East Hanover that was first listed for $539,000 and sat on the market for 80 days with a colonial in Millburn that was listed for $775,000 and sold in two days. 
 Mr. Anthony says he believes the market is still hot as long as three conditions are met: ''nice house, nice location and nice price.'' 
 For all the talk of a bubble, prices do not seem ready to collapse or even edge south, with the exception of houses whose price tags were plainly inflated. Brokers say the $1 million mark seems to be a dividing line: houses priced for less sell quickly, while houses listed for more are sitting longer and, in some cases, going for less than their list prices.
 The most recent statewide real estate data for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut show that housing prices continued to appreciate late last year, but at a less breathless clip than the year before. 
 According to Rae D. Rosen, a senior economist and assistant vice president for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the growth rate in the price of an average house peaked at the same moment in all three states, the third quarter of 2004. New York State saw a 17 percent increase in sales prices for single-family houses, over the same quarter in 2003; Connecticut, 15 percent; and New Jersey, 18.5 percent.
 By comparison, in the last quarter of 2005, housing prices in New York rose 12.6 percent over the year before, 11.9 percent in Connecticut and 14.6 percent in New Jersey. Westchester County's fourth quarter witnessed a more modest increase of 6 percent. And some brokers say that housing prices may be leveling off. 
 ''It's like going from 60 miles per hour to 30 miles per hour,'' Ms. Rosen said of the rise in prices. ''We're just decelerating. It looks like the market is moving away from its peak.''
 Armed with reports of an easing market and steeped in Internet research, some buyers are heading to open houses with raised hopes, expecting to find a house or a condominium they can not only afford but also actually want to inhabit. Some are equating a softening market with falling prices; they are often disappointed.
 ''There doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason to this market,'' said Claudia DeNatale, who recently toured a lackluster three-bedroom condominium in Huntington Station listed for $425,000. ''There's been so much talk about the market changing, but I don't see anything dramatic. When you talk about a drop, it should be significant.''
 What many buyers do report is greater choice. Indeed, inventory -- tight as a noose since 2000 -- is up across the region, sometimes markedly.
 On Long Island, the number of unsold houses in January stood at 23,470, a 67 percent jump from the year before. Inventory in Connecticut also rose. In Fairfield County, the number of houses for sale at the end of last year was 35 percent higher than in late 2004. Inventories in some communities (Norwalk, Easton, New Canaan and Darien) were up more than 50 percent.
 New Jersey's inventory swelled, too, up 46 percent in January over the previous year. Westchester had the least growth in the number of houses on the market, 13 percent more at the end of 2005. If you add in co-ops and condominiums, the rise in inventory was 21 percent.
 The chief executive of Westchester County's real estate board, P. Gilbert Mercurio, said the total number of residential properties now on the market is still less than half that of the mid-1990's. ''The real estate boom ate into the inventory in Westchester County, and it is only now starting to rebuild,'' he said.
 Whatever the exact inventory increases, the effect is a more relaxed home-buying environment. Kelly Sabloff has sampled both markets. In 2001, she and her husband, Matthew, relocating from Montreal, bought an expanded Cape for $515,000 in Stamford, Conn. In February, after selling it for $680,000, they moved a short distance to a center hall colonial, for which they paid $747,000. ''The big difference I noticed was the choice,'' Mrs. Sabloff said. ''Granted I was in a different price range four and a half years later. But there was a sheer volume of choice. You didn't have the pressure of, 'If you don't put an offer down, you're going to lose it.' ''
 Bill Hanley, president-elect of the New Jersey Association of Realtors and manager of Weichert Realtors in Metuchen, agreed. ''Before, we had one home for 10 buyers,'' he said. ''Now the one buyer can look at 10 homes.''
 For sellers, the new market dynamic can lead to frustration. Gary Harman watched in recent years as his neighbors sold Cape Cod-style homes for more than a half-million dollars. At the end of December, he put his house, in East Hanover on the market for $539,000. None of the more than 25 people who went to see it made an offer. He then dropped the price three times, to $499,000, and late last month finally received an offer, which he accepted. 
 He had thought his house would stand out because of the abundant custom wood molding that he installed. ''The discouraging part is that when the people go through the house, they don't even take that into consideration,'' he said. ''You could have holes in the house and it wouldn't matter.'' 
 Other sellers are newly self-conscious about the style of their house. Contemporaries, ranches and split-levels tend to sell more slowly than traditional houses, but that is even more true in a softening market, brokers say. 
 Lori and Greg Margolis have just put their 1960's ranch in Harrison, N.Y., on the market for nearly $2.2 million. It is sizable: 4,000 square feet on one and a half acres. They have transformed the house, which Mrs. Margolis termed a ''complete 1980's abomination,'' by renovating the bathrooms and painting the rooms stark colors. 
 Still, she is approaching the listing with trepidation. ''The market's not vibrant now,'' she said. ''It's a nice house, but it's a certain look. The buyers in Westchester are not eclectic. It's very conservative. This house in L.A. would be the hippest, coolest house. People here like English country.''
 Buyers, for their part, are feeling the pressures of rising interest rates and limited investment potential. The first would seem to propel buyers toward a purchase, so that they can lock in what is still a desirable rate. The second factor -- the possibility that the market may be at its peak -- may suggest caution.
 Brokers say buyers are responding by looking for attributes that tend to prop up a home's value over time, like good schools and attractive commutes. More buyers are taking property taxes into account, too.
 Ruth Chizzini, vice president and director of relocation in Westchester for Sotheby's International Realty, said that escalating property taxes in the county were deterring some. ''When you come to New York, you can live in three states, and buyers are going with value,'' she said. ''We are very impacted by taxes. I just lost a couple of $3 million customers to Connecticut.''
 Of course, some towns in the region enjoy such a buzz that market shifts are not acutely felt. There is Rye, N.Y., on Long Island Sound, with top-rated schools and many old and charming houses (quite a few of them mansions -- without the ''Mc'').
 Last month, a house in the prestigious Milton Point section that was listed for $1.7 million went to a sealed bid, a more civilized take on the bidding war, when the seller's broker asks all potential buyers for their best offers and terms.
 Ms. Chizzini says tear-downs are still common in Rye, another sign of a superheated market: in March a builder closed on a $1.6 million house on less than a half-acre, with plans to knock it down and build anew. And two young couples were recently competing for one of Ms. Chizzini's Rye listings -- a four-bedroom split-level asking $875,000 that, in her words, ''needs everything, everything.''
 But for every situation like that, there is one like the town house listed in late January by Carol Ann Decker, a sales associate in the office of Country Living Associates in Westport, Conn.
 Mrs. Decker put the town house, in Fairfield, Conn., on the market for $535,000. ''We sold it instantly,'' she said. But the buyer got cold feet, she said, and failed to move forward with an inspection. Three other buyers expressed interest but faded away, Mrs. Decker said. It was not until late March that a firm offer was made and accepted.
 ''Three years ago,'' she said, ''I think it would have sold -- and stuck -- right away.''

HEADLINE: A Suburban Switch: The Condo's the Thing

BYLINE: By FERNANDA SANTOS

 BODY:
IN mid-November, Jin Kim and May Yee Yeoung, single professional women who have been roommates for two years, pooled their money and bought their first home, a luxurious two-bedroom condo just off Interstate 95 in Fairfield, Conn., 60 miles north of the rental apartment in TriBeCa where they used to live.
 Two months later, Walter and Lois F. Killough, who have been married 26 years and have two grown children, bought a two-bedroom condo in West New York, just across the Hudson River from Midtown Manhattan. They are slowly moving out of their home in suburban Mahwah so that Mr. Killough can have a shorter commute to work in New York City and Mrs. Killough can be closer to the theaters she loves to attend.
''This feels almost like a vacation home,'' Mrs. Killough, a seventh-grade English teacher, said of her new home at the Hudson Club in Port Imperial, a 200-acre waterfront development that spans five New Jersey cities and towns. 
 ''There's a pool that's right on the edge of the river,'' said Mr. Killough, chief operating officer of Delia's, a retailer of clothing for teenagers. ''There's a whole health club. I can be back home from work in 15 minutes.''
 Although Fairfield and the Hudson waterfront of New Jersey present two distinctly different streetscapes, both sets of homeowners are part of a trend that has the potential to draw a new wave of suburban pioneers to some cities and other densely populated communities. 
 For decades, ornate homes with lush yards and multicar garages have been staples of suburban life and the objects of desire of countless families yearning for better schools, safer streets and greener environs far from the city. But as the scarcity of vacant land drove prices to stratospheric highs and many outlying communities began to impose restrictions to curb sprawl, builders trained their eyes on urban neighborhoods. 
 There they can still buy old or abandoned property at market value, tear it down and replace it with condos, which can be as fancy as a McMansion and as spacious as a single-family home. Though the properties at the high end are not cheap, they typically cost less than a house of comparable luxury and are easier to maintain.
 ''People that used to be able to afford a 1,200- or 1,500-square-foot home in the suburbs are still moving to the suburbs, but buying a 1,200- or 1,500-square-foot condo instead,'' said Tim Cashel, a division manager at Baker Residential, a developer in Pleasantville, N.Y., that is building two condominium communities in Bayonne, a long-neglected city on the Hudson River waterfront.
 ''Condos have become the new starter home for a lot of these folks,'' Mr. Cashel said. ''But because some of these condos are so posh and so close to the city, they have also become a retirement home for many other people who were already living in the suburbs, but were looking to trade their mansions for a smaller place.''
 Developers, spotting an opportunity, have been investing in condo construction at a feverish pace. According to the Crittenden Builders Report, a trade publication, the number of new multifamily condo and town house projects increased by about 50 percent nationwide between 2004 and last year. 
 Much of the new construction has sprouted in urban communities that developers bypassed when they blazed new frontiers deep in the suburbs. Local officials enticed them with tactics like tax incentives, selling public property for a fraction of the price and easing the approval of construction permits. In return, the developers promised to fatten municipal coffers with property tax revenues. 
 ''These days, urban areas are more friendly than the smaller suburban communities because their leaders -- the mayors, the city councilors, the city managers -- they want to see those areas revitalized, they want to see their cities active 24 hours, and the best way to do that is to encourage new construction,'' said Jeffrey Dunne, a vice chairman of CB Richard Ellis in Stamford, Conn., a commercial real estate company that sells buildings for condominium conversion throughout the New York metropolitan area. 
 Suburban cities ''are following the smart growth principles,'' said Richard V. Guarino, dean of the Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University in Hempstead. ''They're creating density where infrastructure already exists, and they're creating this density with mixed-use development in downtown areas, building offices as well as housing so that you can attract young people to live and work there. 
 ''That's critical to the future of these areas because if they're not able to attract young people, they won't be able to sustain their business and economic gains,'' Mr. Guarino said. 
 In the last five years, new condo and rental apartment towers have fueled a renaissance in the working-class enclaves of Union City and Weehawken, which have at least 30 condo projects recently completed, under construction or in the planning stages; and in once-depressed downtown areas of White Plains and New Rochelle in Westchester County, where three condo towers carry Donald Trump's name.
 In Connecticut, condos have brought residents to Stamford's downtown and to an old industrial swath of Fairfield, where a large office and retail complex, Metro Center, will rise along I-95 and across the street from Stone Ridge, the luxury condominium community where Ms. Kim and Ms. Yeoung live.
 Like many of the new condos on the market, theirs is a high-end unit, with stainless-steel appliances and granite counters, 10-foot ceilings and hardwood floors. Ownership comes with free health club membership. Such new luxury condos are not cheap, with prices typically starting around $450,000 for a one-bedroom, and bigger units can cost as much as $1.5 million. Developers are trying to convince whoever will listen that it is not just a home they are selling, but a style of living.
 ''The bottom line is that these people want an easier way to live,'' said Ramin Rezai, project manager at Sterling Plaza Condominium in Great Neck, N.Y., where there is hardly any room for new development. ''They don't want to shovel the driveways. They don't want to deal with the annoyances of a broken boiler.
 ''What they want is comfort and convenience, but they don't want to pay New York City prices for that.''
 That is exactly what lured Ms. Kim and Ms. Yeoung to Fairfield, after a year of renting in Manhattan. The women work long hours at a hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn., and said they did not want to worry about who was going to drop off their suits at the dry cleaners. 
 ''We have a concierge who can do that,'' Ms. Yeoung said. ''And we don't even have to cook breakfast on the weekends because they serve it at the health club.''
 She added: ''We can live here for two, three years, and we can build a lot of equity. Buying this condo was a great investment. And our home, it looks beautiful.''

HEADLINE: They Can Go Home Again

BYLINE: By VALERIE COTSALAS

 BODY:
A PERMANENTLY unfolded futon bed, piles of clothing and the smell of stale smoke make Sean Sciubba's cottage in Sea Cliff, N.Y., seem a lot like a college dorm room.
 ''They call it 'The Studio,' '' Mr. Sciubba, 23, said of the friends who visit, weary of the childhood bedrooms they have returned to in their own parents' homes.
Mr. Sciubba's loftlike converted garage behind his mother's lavender Victorian affords him more privacy.
 ''The only time I see my mother is when I'm in the office,'' Mr. Sciubba said. Both work at Sherlock Holmes Realty in Sea Cliff on Long Island; he is the rental manager and she is a real estate agent. 
 It is hardly news that 20- and 30-somethings are living with their parents, camped in a back cottage or a childhood bedroom. The arrangement passes for entertainment, from the Fox sitcom ''Free Ride,'' about a college graduate who moves back in with his parents, to the comedy ''Failure to Launch,'' starring Matthew McConaughey and Sarah Jessica Parker, about a 35-year-old man who never left home.
 But the cost of real estate is making plenty of strange housefellows, with siblings, elderly parents and children, work mates and friends doubling up to save on the mortgage or rent.
 Some local governments are cracking down on cohabitants who are not related. In extreme cases, where day laborers and other immigrants are crowded into houses meant for single families, they are evicting.
 Even the classic ''mother-daughter'' arrangement -- a single-family home with an apartment added for a parent -- is increasingly likely to be illegal, as the cost of building such an apartment to conform to building and zoning codes can run up to $100,000.
 And yet people all over the suburbs are making shared housing work, with some finding happiness and comfort in living with those they know and maybe even love.
 ''It doesn't feel that crowded since they're all family,'' said Ismama Joseph, 52, who lives in a four-bedroom duplex in Norwalk, Conn., with her husband, two adult daughters, their husbands and the five grandchildren she cares for while the others are at work. ''But it would be impossible with strangers.'' 
 In Fairfield County, Conn., many older people -- ''people who have lived their entire lives in Norwalk'' -- are selling and moving in with their children, according to Carol Ann Falasca, a broker at Coldwell Banker Real Estate in Norwalk. ''Their children went to the schools here and all of a sudden they're retired and they cannot afford to stay because of the taxes,'' she said. 
 In New Jersey, Gordon Crawford, a real estate agent with Re/Max Properties Unlimited in Morristown, said about 10 percent of his buyers have been groups of family members buying together. 
 One such group included Suzanne Rosengold, a single mother, who was living last year with her daughter, Hanna, in a one-bedroom rental apartment in Parsippany in the same complex as her parents.
 When Ms. Rosengold's grandfather died last year, the family inherited a Florida condominium that they sold, planning to use the proceeds for a down payment on a house.
 After looking at dozens of houses, the Rosengolds found a four-bedroom ranch in Lake Hiawatha, a suburb of Parsippany. All three generations moved in last July -- the first time any of them had owned a home.
 The mortgage payment is the same as the combined rents the Rosengolds were paying before. ''It has really changed our whole lives,'' Ms. Rosengold said. ''My daughter has her own room now. Before, she had a converted dining room.''
 Her father, Edward Rosengold, 63, said: ''I do things now that I've never done before. I have my own workshop. I build things, I repair things.'' 
 In another three-generation household, in Fairfield, Conn., Christina and Raul Diaz live in a three-bedroom 1,750-square-foot ranch with Mr. Diaz's 59-year-old mother, Leonor Martinez. Ms. Martinez takes care of the couple's 2-year-old daughter, while they work in nearby Stamford.
 But the household will be growing, Ms. Diaz said. Her mother, Beth Bodnar, 70, who recently retired, is moving in soon, and the couple hope to have another baby next year. 
 Ms. Diaz has been looking for about four months for a bigger house that the family can afford in Fairfield. They need about 2,500 square feet and, ideally, a ground-floor master bedroom, she said. 
 But pickings are slim.
 ''We're probably going to have to put it off another year to save more,'' Ms. Diaz said. 
 The couple are assuming that the real estate market is not going to change at all, she added. ''My big concern is how much equity we can get out of our existing house, because I feel like it's a buyer's market, not a seller's market,'' she said.
 Baby boomers reaching retirement age who want to move to a warmer climate are also increasingly helping their adult children expand their homes or buy a larger house. 
 They don't want to lose total contact with their lives here after moving to Florida or Arizona, said Elayne Jassey, a real estate agent with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Stamford. 
 Expanding one's living space to accommodate a relative may be a good investment, in spite of the cost of complying with zoning codes and the possibility of higher property taxes. 
 While ''real estate prices have exploded,'' said Robert Campbell, professor of real estate finance at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., construction costs have risen more slowly with inflation. Under those conditions, he said, ''building onto your own house is one of the best things that you can possibly do.'' 
 But where young people are concerned, multigenerational living is often seen as temporary. Matt Wolff, 31, has been living at his parents' home in White Plains, N.Y., for two years since friends with whom he shared an apartment in Bronxville, N.Y., went their separate ways.
 Mr. Wolff is saving for a down payment on a co-op, ''the last bastion of affordability'' in the area, according to his father, Nick Wolff, who owns Century 21 Wolff, a six-office real estate agency based in White Plains.
 ''It's not a problem for us,'' the senior Mr. Wolff said of his son's situation, ''but from his standpoint, he's a grown man and wants to be on his own and have privacy.''
 On Long Island, Sean Sciubba also says he won't stay in his mother's cottage forever. ''I work in real estate,'' he said. ''I've done the research. Hopefully, I'll be able to get out of there soon.''

 Christina and Raul Diaz of Fairfield, Conn., seek a home to accommodate both of their mothers. (Photo by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Here to Stay. For Now.

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
AFTER living for 14 years on four acres in Bedford, N.Y., Greg Smith and Deborah Dodds were ready for a change. With 9-year-old twins, they wanted a home in a neighborhood, the kind of place where there are lots of kids and a spare cup of sugar is as close as the kitchen next door.
 They found just the place, a four-year-old colonial on a cul-de-sac in the same Westchester town, and they put in an offer, but reconsidered when they could not get what they wanted for their five-bedroom, three-bath home, which they priced near $1.3 million. Rather than move, they have decided to invest in improvements to the home, a 1960's colonial, even though they still intend to move in the next couple of years.
''We don't want to build the Taj Mahal,'' Ms. Dodds said. ''We'll live here maybe two years afterward. We want it to be comfortable and economical.'' 
 It is a delicate balancing act. According to suburban homeowners, designers and builders, remodeling projects are increasingly being influenced by the uncertainty of the real estate market. When do you reach for the stars and when do you stick with the basics? For each homeowner, the answer is different. 
 Ms. Dodds said she and her husband examined their own needs while considering the comments of potential buyers who toured the house. The couple had already redone the kitchen, but, according to the real estate broker's feedback, buyers said they would have liked the house better if the master bathroom had been updated and if the house had a larger family room.
 ''We learned some things by putting it on the market,'' said Ms. Dodds, who runs two businesses from her home, one selling high-end women's clothing and the other teaching scrapbooking. ''It's very hard to compete against new construction.''
 Working with the interior designer Susan Marocco of Bedford, the couple decided to upgrade the bathroom for about $8,000. ''I don't have time to do a gut,'' Ms. Dodds said.
 That is not to say Mr. Smith and Ms. Dodds are not going to make some major improvements. They are planning to expand into the garage to create a large family room off the kitchen and build a separate two-car garage with a second story that could be used as an office or in-law apartment. The cost of that project has not been determined but could be in the neighborhood of $100,000, Ms. Dodds said.
 ''It will help with resale and make us comfortable the next couple of years,'' she said. 
 Like Mr. Smith and Ms. Dodds, Steven P. Grossman is remodeling his home, a 1970's high ranch in Bellmore, N.Y., with an eye to selling it as well as for his own comfort. 
 Mr. Grossman, who listed the Long Island house about 18 months ago, could not sell it, even after he dropped the price $200,000 to $895,000; following the advice of his real estate agent, he had made no improvements before putting the house on the market. This time, he is taking a different approach.
 Based on buyers' negative comments, he created a plan to solve problems while making himself happy. He is replacing windows, altering the facade and putting on new decks. He has plans to upgrade the kitchen, gut the bathrooms and make cosmetic changes throughout.
 To treat himself, he replaced old sliding glass doors with a wall of windows that accentuate the water views.
 ''Every day I walk upstairs in my house and say that's the best money I spent,'' he said.
 Mr. Grossman estimates the cost of the improvements between $100,000 and $150,000 and says he has carefully assessed costs based on the impact the improvements may have on resale.
 For example, while he will be putting new stainless steel appliances in the kitchen, he did not go for the top of the line. Rather than removing old cabinetry, he is having it painted and new hardware put on.
 ''I'm hedging whether I'm staying or going,'' he said. ''I didn't want to go full bore because one never knows if this is a bubble and when the bubble might burst.''
 Besides the real estate market and their personal comfort, Catherine and Stephen Candland of Greenwich, Conn., had one more consideration as they have restored and updated their turn of the century Arts and Crafts home for nearly 10 years: maintaining the architectural integrity of the house.
 Their major projects included turning an addition that once housed a doctor's office into a kitchen, family room, spare guest rooms and office. The third-floor attic was turned into bedrooms for two daughters, a family room, bathroom and laundry room. A master bedroom was created, a pool and patio added and numerous small steps taken to restore architectural features to the home.
 Now, with three daughters ages 13, 17 and 20, the Candlands think they are short-timers in the house. As they move forward on what will probably be their final major project, working with Stephanie Ladoff-Koch, the owner of Ladd Design of New Canaan, Conn., they are also factoring in how far they want to go in an uncertain market.
 ''We could have spent twice or even three times what we were going to spend on this project,'' Ms. Candland said. ''We decided we would balance it with our original three goals. 
 ''Historically Greenwich has held its value, but I think a number of things are happening in Connecticut and it's naive to assume that things won't slow down.''
 While they knew they wanted to take down a wall to open up the entryway, a decision on whether to add a stone gas fireplace had to be carefully weighed against what it would cost to open a hidden flue. 
 The Candlands decided to go with a fireplace, but chose electric, an alternative that would not require opening up the flue. 
 For some homeowners, especially those who expect to be staying put for a while, comfort outweighs the investment factor in home improvement. Darlene Branch and her husband, Leonard, of Orange, had hoped to move to a community with a better school system but found themselves priced out of the market in nearby places like Montclair and Glen Ridge and are considering private school for their children.
 For now, they are altering their six-bedroom Victorian home to better suit their needs as well as those of their 4-year-old twins. Ms. Branch said they went ahead with a $16,000 basement remodeling so the children would have a place to play, even though she was told the improvement would not contribute much to the home's resale value. 
 The Branches put off a major kitchen remodeling, choosing instead to invest in new windows and convert the oil furnace to gas for future energy savings. This summer she will make improvements to the outside of the house, replacing gutters and painting.
 Ms. Branch is also working with an interior designer, Nicole Bouknight, of Bloomfield to redecorate the children's rooms and the living areas on the first floor.
 ''Even if you did all the renovations in the world, I don't think the market is going to hold,'' Ms. Branch said. ''So we decided let's do what makes us happy.''

 Deborah Dodds, left, and her designer, Susan Marocco, at Ms. Dodds's home in Bedford, N.Y. (Photo by Susan Stava for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Other Pension Crisis

BYLINE: By Christian E. Weller. 
Christian E. Weller is a senior economist at the Center for American Progress.

DATELINE: Washington 

 BODY:
RECENT concerns about pensions in New Jersey have focused on the budget question: where will New Jersey find the approximately $2 billion it needs to keep its pension promises to state employees this year? 
 That is a substantial problem, but over the long term, it is not the state's biggest. Looming even larger are low levels of pension coverage and retirement security for New Jerseyans employed in the private sector. Over time, as New Jersey workers retire with increasingly inadequate savings, the state's Medicaid and public assistance programs will face a growing burden.
To be sure, the state government's problem must be dealt with. The pension crisis today is a result of two factors. The first is a market change -- the sharp decline in both the stock market and interest rates, a combination unseen since the Great Depression. These bear markets cut the money available to pay current and future benefits. In 2004, New Jersey had 87 percent of what it needed, compared with 111 percent in 2000. The second cause of the public pensions crisis is state lawmakers, who acted just like private employers by taking advantage of technical rules to reduce pension contributions. As a result, pension plans were less prepared for the end of Wall Street's golden years. 
 Faced with a budget deficit of $4.3 billion, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has proposed to contribute $1.5 billion to state pensions this year -- a respectable 70 percent of the current pension obligation. But small changes in how New Jersey finances its pensions can insure the health of these plans for the long run. Among the most important changes is the requirement that the state make regular contributions -- a change that would end efforts to avoid pension contributions when times are good and a change that might have saved us from the current budgetary crunch. 
 Another fix to the system is to end what's called ''padding and boosting,'' a practice intended to increase pension benefits through end-of-career spikes in earnings. This can happen when people take on multiple jobs at the end of their career with the goal of increasing their pension. While ending these practices would save the state only $7.2 million a year according to the Benefits Review Task Force, the great benefit would be the likely boost in public confidence and support for the system. 
 As pensions in the public sector are both sustainable and likely to remain in place, our major concern should be with the frightening lack of pension coverage in the private sector. With only 45 percent of private workers in New Jersey covered by a pension, New Jersey ranks 26th among the 50 states and the District of Columbia. 
 Strategic reforms could go a long way to improving pension coverage in the private sector. Although the federal government will have to take on most of the burden, the state has an opportunity here to encourage and assist employers who might want to provide pensions but are perhaps wary of the costs of administration. 
 For example, the state could establish a separate 401(k)-style fund that would be open to all employers who want to participate. Such a plan could significantly lower the costs of saving for retirement, letting people keep more of their own money. The plan would presumably be large and administered by the state. Investments would be spread out among a variety of stock and bond funds, ensuring lower financial risks than in private-sector 401(k) plans, some of which invest in a single company's stock. Similar proposals have been made for Washington State, under the Washington Voluntary Accounts proposal, and, most recently, for Michigan by Gov. Jennifer Granholm. 
 Any calculation of the exact government savings from better pension coverage is extremely speculative. But better coverage might keep one-quarter to and one-half of low-income elderly residents off public assistance. That, in turn, could reduce state and federal spending on such programs by 5 percent to 10 percent. If such programs were already in place, they could lower government spending in New Jersey in 2007 by $400 million to $800 million.
 While increased pension coverage is the primary goal, New Jersey will probably never reach 100 percent coverage and therefore will need also to encourage saving for those without any formal pension. States can and should play an active role in making it easier for people to save. Some of the strongest proposals to make employees save more are those that make saving more automatic. 
 One such proposal is the ''automatic'' individual retirement account developed by Mark Iwry of the Brookings Institution and David John of the Heritage Foundation. With an ''automatic I.R.A.,'' every company above a certain size, in this case 10 employees, would have to offer automatic payroll deduction into an I.R.A. for their employees. The process would be similar to the direct deposits of paychecks. Employees would have the option to decline, but studies show that when you make someone opt out as opposed to asking them to opt in, most will stay in. Establishing an easy way for people to save would greatly increase retirement security for many workers in New Jersey.
 So by all means, let's tackle the budgetary crisis created by public sector pensions. But as we do, let's not forget the potentially even greater shortfall in the private sector. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Labor Talks: Don't Worry, There Must Be Something to Fight Over

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
IN most years that are the last of a labor agreement, labor would be the issue that would command the top spot on the list of potentially thorny problems facing Major League Baseball. This year, though, labor will take a distant second place to the thorn in Commissioner Bud Selig's side that is named Barry Bonds.
 Last month, Selig said he'd rather have a root canal than have to answer questions about Bonds. If that didn't put his feelings in perspective, try this: He'd rather argue with Don Fehr about revenue sharing and luxury taxes than have to deal with the problems Bonds has created. Selig will get his chance. 
 The collective-bargaining agreement expires Dec. 19, and the two sides have had background talks. They may begin their negotiations as early as this month. 
 It's much too early, though, to determine where the talks will head and how they'll wind up. The last negotiation, in 2002, was concluded amicably, but every negotiation before that, beginning in 1972, resulted in a strike or a lockout.
 Fehr said last week that he was out of the prediction business, but in response to a question after a speech in San Francisco in early February, he said, ''I'd like to believe the atmosphere of lower levels of public dispute is going to be maintained.''
 Right, until either side proposes something for which the other side has no use. When that happens -- and it will -- the issue will be economic. It probably won't be a salary cap, which the owners, envious of the N.F.L., the N.B.A. and the N.H.L., have tried for years to attain. Fehr said in his speech: ''I would be very surprised if we were talking about salary caps. I think that issue is behind us, and that's positive.''
 Baseball has flourished economically in recent years, and the owners would be hard pressed to make proposals based on economic hardship. Industry revenue didn't reach $2 billion until 1997, and last year it soared to $4.7 billion. In the same period, the average salary rose to just shy of $2.5 million, from $1.3 million.
 Obviously, revenues have risen at a faster rate than salaries, and players are making a smaller percentage of the total revenue than they did a decade ago. 
 The problem in baseball isn't industry revenue; it's the disparity of revenue among the 30 clubs. The Yankees generate far greater revenue than the Kansas City Royals and spend far more on players, too.
 That was the point Selig made in a television appearance earlier this year, saying he would seek to increase the revenue going to low-revenue clubs from high-revenue clubs. If there is going to be a labor fight, that effort is where it will probably start. 
 Clubs already share national revenue equally, but unlike the situation in the N.F.L., baseball revenue is mostly local. Under the current agreement, clubs share 34 percent of their local revenue.
 What business is it of the union how much revenue the clubs share? The union cares because the amount a paying club gives up can affect its decisions on how much it will pay its players. The luxury tax figures in that process, too.
 Last year, the Yankees paid more in luxury tax ($34 million) and revenue sharing ($75 million) combined than 28 of the other 29 teams paid their players. The previous winter, the Yankees could have signed Carlos Beltran for a discounted $100 million, but they opted not to because the contract would have cost an extra $40 million in luxury tax.
 That's the sort of thing that bothers the union. Whether it's the Yankees or any other club, if any payment inhibits spending on player salaries, that payment is not attractive to the union.
 Before entertaining any club proposals on revenue sharing, the union will scrutinize how clubs have spent the money they have received. The current agreement states that a club will use what it receives from revenue sharing ''in an effort to improve its performance on the field.''
 Some members of the union are not convinced that all of the clubs who have received revenue-sharing money have followed that provision.
 Fehr has completed team-by-team spring-training meetings and has received the players' views on issues that are important to them. 
 One issue that was discussed was how Selig used his Congressional hammer to force the union into agreeing to a tougher steroid-testing plan in what amounted to an unprecedented second reopening of an existing collective-bargaining agreement (the first reopening was unprecedented as well).
 Selig's stance will probably harden the attitudes of many players and create a more militant attitude than may have otherwise existed. 
 No matter what happens in negotiations, neither side can take any action threatening the season. 
 The agreement reached peacefully in 2002 was unexpected and stunning. When no strike or lockout developed, one person who had experienced nothing but strikes and lockouts felt empty and lost, as he did in 1994 when there was no World Series to culminate the season. 
 A club president had once accused me of favoring the forces of instability, and at that moment there was no instability to favor.


GRAPHIC: Photo: Commissioner Bud Selig's pursuit of tougher steroid testing may increase the players' militancy. (Photo by Mary Altaffer/Associated Press)

HEADLINE: What's Next? A Zipper Board?

BYLINE: By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
THE billboard is 48 feet wide and 14 feet high, but what really sets it apart from the others on Interstate 95 in Bridgeport are the tens of thousands of colored digital lights and images that change every few seconds. It is a bit of Times Square in Connecticut and the second such sign in the state, with more to come. 
 Lamar Advertising, a company in Baton Rouge, La., that owns more than 1,000 billboards in Connecticut, recently put up the first of two full-sized L.E.D. models it has planned for I-95 in Bridgeport. It has had a similar billboard on I-84 in Hartford for about two years. The Legislature passed a law allowing the signs, which are very noticeable, two years ago.
''We certainly don't want a distraction to take away anyone's attention from a moving vehicle on a highway in the state,'' said Sgt. J. Paul Vance, a spokesman for the State Police. ''These boards are very bright and visible, especially at night, and do have a tendency to draw a driver's attention. It's a concern for us, but we have no control over them.''
 Sergeant Vance said that there have been no accidents tied to drivers being distracted by the signs.
 Chris Cooper, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation, said that according to the law, each message must be on the board for at least six seconds and the new messages must be displayed within three seconds to prevent drivers from getting distracted, he said.
 Mr. Cooper said the State Department of Public Safety, at a hearing before the law was passed, testified that the boards could be a distraction.
 He also said too many of the boards could become a problem. He said that the law doesn't address this issue, but that the D.O.T. would be watching to see how many would be put up.
 ''We do monitor that kind of signage,'' he said, noting that companies must obtain permits from the agency for the signs. ''Although it's unclear what we would be able to do without legislative change.''
 William J. Ripp, the director of digital advertising for Lamar, said the company had put up about 75 L.E.D. billboards across the country at a cost of about $500,000 each. The signs can display rotating messages, so Lamar can sell the time on each board to more than one advertiser.
 He said the boards were designed to not be distracting. He also said he did not believe there would be a great proliferation of them on the highways.
 ''The cost of these is quite high, so I just don't see the economics panning out in that kind of fashion,'' he said.
 Stephen Freitas, the chief marketing officer for the Outdoor Advertising Association of America in Washington, said there are about 100 L.E.D. billboards in the United States. He said he expected that number to double this year.
 Mr. Freitas said Delaware, New Hampshire, North Dakota and Wyoming are the only states that do not have legislation allowing the boards.
 ''Because this is a new technology, they don't have provisions on the books yet,'' he said.

HEADLINE: A Suburban Switch: The Condo's the Thing

BYLINE: By FERNANDA SANTOS

 BODY:
IN mid-November, Jin Kim and May Yee Yeoung, single professional women who have been roommates for two years, pooled their money and bought their first home, a luxurious two-bedroom condo just off Interstate 95 in Fairfield, Conn., 60 miles north of the rental apartment in TriBeCa where they used to live.
 Two months later, Walter and Lois F. Killough, who have been married 26 years and have two grown children, bought a two-bedroom condo in West New York, N.J., just across the Hudson River from Midtown Manhattan. They are slowly moving out of their home in suburban Mahwah, N.J., so that Mr. Killough can have a shorter commute to work in New York City and Mrs. Killough can be closer to the theaters she loves to attend.
''This feels almost like a vacation home,'' Mrs. Killough, a seventh-grade English teacher, said of her new home at the Hudson Club in Port Imperial, a 200-acre waterfront development that spans five New Jersey cities and towns. 
 ''There's a pool that's right on the edge of the river,'' said Mr. Killough, chief operating officer of Delia's, a retailer of clothing for teenagers. ''There's a whole health club. I can be back home from work in 15 minutes.''
 Although Fairfield and the Hudson waterfront of New Jersey present two distinctly different streetscapes, both sets of homeowners are part of a trend that has the potential to draw a new wave of suburban pioneers to some cities and other densely populated communities. 
 For decades, ornate homes with lush yards and multicar garages have been staples of suburban life and the objects of desire of countless families yearning for better schools, safer streets and greener environs far from the city. But as the scarcity of vacant land drove prices to stratospheric highs and many outlying communities began to impose restrictions to curb sprawl, builders trained their eyes on urban neighborhoods. 
 There they can still buy old or abandoned property at market value, tear it down and replace it with condos, which can be as fancy as a McMansion and as spacious as a single-family home. Though the properties at the high end are not cheap, they typically cost less than a house of comparable luxury and are easier to maintain.
 ''People that used to be able to afford a 1,200- or 1,500-square-foot home in the suburbs are still moving to the suburbs, but buying a 1,200- or 1,500-square-foot condo instead,'' said Tim Cashel, a division manager at Baker Residential, a developer in Pleasantville, N.Y., that is building two condominium communities in Bayonne, N.J., a long-neglected city on the Hudson River waterfront.
 ''Condos have become the new starter home for a lot of these folks,'' Mr. Cashel said. ''But because some of these condos are so posh and so close to the city, they have also become a retirement home for many other people who were already living in the suburbs, but were looking to trade their mansions for a smaller place.''
 Developers, spotting an opportunity, have been investing in condo construction at a feverish pace. According to the Crittenden Builders Report, a trade publication, the number of new multifamily condo and town house projects increased by about 50 percent nationwide between 2004 and last year. 
 Much of the new construction has sprouted in urban communities that developers bypassed when they blazed new frontiers deep in the suburbs. Local officials enticed them with tactics like tax incentives, selling public property for a fraction of the price and easing the approval of construction permits. In return, the developers promised to fatten municipal coffers with property tax revenues. 
 ''These days, urban areas are more friendly than the smaller suburban communities because their leaders -- the mayors, the city councilors, the city managers -- they want to see those areas revitalized, they want to see their cities active 24 hours, and the best way to do that is to encourage new construction,'' said Jeffrey Dunne, a vice chairman of CB Richard Ellis in Stamford, Conn., a commercial real estate company that sells buildings for condominium conversion throughout the New York metropolitan area. 
 Suburban cities ''are following the smart growth principles,'' said Richard V. Guarino, dean of the Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University in Hempstead. ''They're creating density where infrastructure already exists, and they're creating this density with mixed-use development in downtown areas, building offices as well as housing so that you can attract young people to live and work there. 
 ''That's critical to the future of these areas because if they're not able to attract young people, they won't be able to sustain their business and economic gains,'' Mr. Guarino said. 
 In the last five years, new condo and rental apartment towers have fueled a renaissance in the working-class enclaves of Union City, N.J., and Weehawken, N.J., which have at least 30 condo projects recently completed, under construction or in the planning stages; and in once-depressed downtown areas of White Plains and New Rochelle in Westchester County, where three condo towers carry Donald Trump's name.
 In Connecticut, condos have brought residents to Stamford's downtown and to an old industrial swath of Fairfield, where a large office and retail complex, Metro Center, will rise along I-95 and across the street from Stone Ridge, the luxury condominium community where Ms. Kim and Ms. Yeoung live.
 Like many of the new condos on the market, theirs is a high-end unit, with stainless-steel appliances and granite counters, 10-foot ceilings and hardwood floors. Ownership comes with free health club membership. Such new luxury condos are not cheap, with prices typically starting around $450,000 for a one-bedroom, and bigger units can cost as much as $1.5 million. Developers are trying to convince whoever will listen that it is not just a home they are selling, but also a style of living.
 ''The bottom line is that these people want an easier way to live,'' said Ramin Rezai, project manager at Sterling Plaza Condominium in Great Neck, where there is hardly any room for new development. ''They don't want to shovel the driveways. They don't want to deal with the annoyances of a broken boiler.
 ''What they want is comfort and convenience, but they don't want to pay New York City prices for that.''
 That is exactly what lured Ms. Kim and Ms. Yeoung to Fairfield, after a year of renting in Manhattan. The women work long hours at a hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn., and said they did not want to worry about who was going to drop off their suits at the dry cleaners. 
 ''We have a concierge who can do that,'' Ms. Yeoung said. ''And we don't even have to cook breakfast on the weekends because they serve it at the health club.''
 She added: ''We can live here for two, three years, and we can build a lot of equity. Buying this condo was a great investment. And our home, it looks beautiful.''

HEADLINE: They Can Go Home Again

BYLINE: By VALERIE COTSALAS

 BODY:
A PERMANENTLY unfolded futon bed, piles of clothing and the smell of stale smoke make Sean Sciubba's cottage in Sea Cliff seem a lot like a college dorm room.
 ''They call it 'The Studio,' '' Mr. Sciubba, 23, said of the friends who visit, weary of the childhood bedrooms they have returned to in their own parents' homes.
Mr. Sciubba's loftlike converted garage behind his mother's lavender Victorian affords him more privacy.
 ''The only time I see my mother is when I'm in the office,'' Mr. Sciubba said. Both work at Sherlock Holmes Realty in Sea Cliff; he is the rental manager and she is a real estate agent. 
 It is hardly news that 20- and 30-somethings are living with their parents, camped in a back cottage or a childhood bedroom. The arrangement passes for entertainment, from the Fox sitcom ''Free Ride,'' about a college graduate who moves back in with his parents, to the comedy ''Failure to Launch,'' starring Matthew McConaughey and Sarah Jessica Parker, about a 35-year-old man who never left home.
 But the cost of real estate is making plenty of strange housefellows, with siblings, elderly parents and children, work mates and friends doubling up to save on the mortgage or rent.
 Some local governments are cracking down on cohabitants who are not related. In extreme cases, where day laborers and other immigrants are crowded into houses meant for single families, they are evicting.
 Even the classic ''mother-daughter'' arrangement -- a single-family home with an apartment added for a parent -- is increasingly likely to be illegal, as the cost of building such an apartment to conform to building and zoning codes can run up to $100,000.
 And yet people all over the suburbs are making shared housing work, with some finding happiness and comfort in living with those they know and maybe even love.
 ''It doesn't feel that crowded since they're all family,'' said Ismama Joseph, 52, who lives in a four-bedroom duplex in Norwalk, Conn., with her husband, two adult daughters, their husbands and the five grandchildren she cares for while the others are at work. ''But it would be impossible with strangers.'' 
 In Fairfield County, Conn., many older people -- ''people who have lived their entire lives in Norwalk'' -- are selling and moving in with their children, according to Carol Ann Falasca, a broker at Coldwell Banker Real Estate in Norwalk. ''Their children went to the schools here and all of a sudden they're retired and they cannot afford to stay because of the taxes,'' she said. 
 In New Jersey, Gordon Crawford, a real estate agent with Re/Max Properties Unlimited in Morristown, said about 10 percent of his buyers have been groups of family members buying together. 
 One such group included Suzanne Rosengold, a single mother, who was living last year with her daughter, Hanna, in a one-bedroom rental apartment in Parsippany, N.J., in the same complex as her parents.
 When Ms. Rosengold's grandfather died last year, the family inherited a Florida condominium that they sold, planning to use the proceeds for a down payment on a house.
 After looking at dozens of houses, the Rosengolds found a four-bedroom ranch in Lake Hiawatha, a suburb of Parsippany. All three generations moved in last July -- the first time any of them had owned a home.
 The mortgage payment is the same as the combined rents the Rosengolds were paying before. ''It has really changed our whole lives,'' Ms. Rosengold said. ''My daughter has her own room now. Before, she had a converted dining room.''
 Her father, Edward Rosengold, 63, said: ''I do things now that I've never done before. I have my own workshop. I build things, I repair things.'' 
 In another three-generation household, in Fairfield, Conn., Christina and Raul Diaz live in a three-bedroom 1,750-square-foot ranch with Mr. Diaz's 59-year-old mother, Leonor Martinez. Ms. Martinez takes care of the couple's 2-year-old daughter, while they work in nearby Stamford.
 But the household will be growing, Ms. Diaz said. Her mother, Beth Bodnar, 70, who recently retired, is moving in soon, and the couple hope to have another baby next year. 
 Ms. Diaz has been looking for about four months for a bigger house that the family can afford in Fairfield. They need about 2,500 square feet and, ideally, a ground-floor master bedroom, she said. 
 But pickings are slim.
 ''We're probably going to have to put it off another year to save more,'' Ms. Diaz said. 
 The couple are assuming that the real estate market is not going to change at all, she added. ''My big concern is how much equity we can get out of our existing house, because I feel like it's a buyer's market, not a seller's market,'' she said.
 Baby boomers reaching retirement age who want to move to a warmer climate are also increasingly helping their adult children expand their homes or buy a larger house. 
 They don't want to lose total contact with their lives here after moving to Florida or Arizona, said Elayne Jassey, a real estate agent with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Stamford. 
 Expanding one's living space to accommodate a relative may be a good investment, in spite of the cost of complying with zoning codes and the possibility of higher property taxes. 
 While ''real estate prices have exploded,'' said Robert Campbell, professor of real estate finance at Hofstra University in Hempstead, construction costs have risen more slowly with inflation. Under those conditions, he said, ''building onto your own house is one of the best things that you can possibly do.'' 
 But where young people are concerned, multigenerational living is often seen as temporary. Matt Wolff, 31, has been living at his parents' home in White Plains for two years since friends with whom he shared an apartment in Bronxville went their separate ways.
 Mr. Wolff is saving for a down payment on a co-op, ''the last bastion of affordability'' in the area, according to his father, Nick Wolff, who owns Century 21 Wolff, a six-office real estate agency based in White Plains.
 ''It's not a problem for us,'' the senior Mr. Wolff said of his son's situation, ''but from his standpoint, he's a grown man and wants to be on his own and have privacy.''
 On Long Island, Sean Sciubba also says he won't stay in his mother's cottage forever. ''I work in real estate,'' he said. ''I've done the research. Hopefully, I'll be able to get out of there soon.''

HEADLINE: The Cost of Staying Out of Jail

BYLINE: By Kirsten D. Levingston. 
Kirsten D. Levingston is the director of the criminal justice program at the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law.

 BODY:
WHEN he released his budget in January, Gov. George Pataki boasted that New York was the safest large state in the nation. He also proposed programs to help people leaving prison ''become productive, law-abiding citizens.'' Indeed, the governor rightly links a convict's reintegration into society with public safety. 
 But nestled in Governor Pataki's budget is a proposal that would make it far harder for people on probation -- those sentenced to a period of correctional supervision in their communities instead of in prison -- to rejoin those communities and enter the economic mainstream. The governor's plan authorizes every county and the City of New York to pile thousands of dollars in fees and fines on probationers. 
These new fees would pay for the cost of things like electronic monitoring, drug testing and DNA databank submissions, adding more than $3,500 to an already daunting array of financial punishments that include the costs of, among other things, a crime-victim assistance fee and a cash bail fee that people convicted of crimes may face. Moreover, probationers must pay off these monetary obligations before they can emerge from probation supervision. 
 Today, these fees and fines serve varied purposes. Some are intended to punish or make a victim whole. Others are assessed to offset administrative costs, like probation supervision expenses. Still others raise funds that go into government coffers for general use, like the DNA databank fee. 
 Governor Pataki's proposal has nothing to do with compensating victims. It simply allows local governments to offset the cost of supervising people on probation, essentially creating a probationer's tax. Twenty years ago, in weighing the pros and cons of probation fees, the National Institute of Corrections, an agency within the United States Department of Justice, said that fees like these ''represent double taxation: the assessment of a user fee is, in reality, payment for services already supported by general taxes paid by probationers.''
 Strangely enough, many of these fees and fines may be far harsher than the original punishment. Most probationers are not convicted of felonies, but are guilty of misdemeanors, petty offenses not punished by long jail time. Yet failure to pay fees and fines can land them in jail even if their actual offenses did not. While this sounds like something out of a Dickens novel, examples of this are multiplying as fees and fines are increased across the country.
 To be sure, financial punishment sounds like a relatively painless way of being tough on crime. After all, if given the choice between a financial penalty or time in prison, most of us would gladly reach into our pockets. And the state avoids the cost of actually locking someone up when fees and fines replace cell time. But this solution is merely the latest example of a policy that erects barriers to successful reintegration into society for those convicted of crimes. 
 Like the rest of us, many people on probation face multiple financial obligations. They are supporting families, paying rent or mortgages and making sure the lights stay on. Unlike the general population, however, some 80 percent of defendants in the justice system are indigent, according to the Center for Community Alternatives, a nonprofit organization that closely monitors these fees in New York. 
 If a $3,500 debt matters to you, imagine what it would mean to a poor person with a criminal conviction who is struggling to get a decent job and either return to the mainstream economy or enter it for the first time. The mere appearance of a justice system-imposed obligation on someone's credit history can flag a criminal history even if a court has sealed or erased a person's criminal record, or if the conviction information is years old, making it even more difficult to land a job.
 According to the National Institute of Corrections, ''The added stress caused by inability to pay may cause probationers to miss appointments, thus negating any positive effect of supervision and sometimes resulting in revocation for failure to comply with the conditions of probation.'' 
 Acknowledging that fees and fines can be a ball and chain that hold people back, the Council of State Governments, a nonprofit good governance group, has urged states to strike an ''especially careful balance between achieving reparative justice (for the victim or community), meeting the needs of the released person's family and creating a manageable, if difficult, obligation for the individual.'' 
 Governor Pataki's proposal does not strike that balance. It would be folly to proclaim our devotion to re-entry of prisoners into society with the one hand, while imposing financial burdens with the other that will make it harder for them to get jobs and stay out of jail.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
