HEADLINE: Misses and Hits

BYLINE: By Rob Walker. 
E-mail: consumed@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Big Lots
 Is the marketplace perfectly efficient? If producer supply and shopper demand always synched up just right, then perhaps there would be no reason for a chain like Big Lots to exist. Big Lots has about 1,400 locations around the United States and revenue of $4.4 billion in its most recently concluded fiscal year. The chain specializes in ''closeouts.'' There are many kinds of closeout merchandise, but what this often means in practice is that unlike a store that tries to figure out where the demand is and get the proper supply in stock to meet it, Big Lots starts with supply and seeks demand. 
Late last year, for example, Big Lots offered 20-inch Huffy Chopper bicycles for about $60 (or even $50, during holiday-season sales). When Huffy manufactured the bikes, the idea was that they would be sold at retailers like Wal-Mart and Kmart for a price closer to $100. But Huffy has had a very rough ride in recent years. (It re-emerged from bankruptcy in 2005.) ''They had large quantities of this product on hand,'' says John Martin, Big Lots' executive vice president for merchandising, ''but it was being discontinued by the retailers who had stocked it.'' Big Lots had never offered bicycles in large quantities before but bought half the 35,000 bikes to see what would happen. They ''blew out'' the doors, Martin says. So the chain bought the rest of the bikes and put them on sale in March. 
 About half of the typical Big Lots selling floor is given over to closeouts like those Huffy bikes, each one offering a particular narrative on the imperfections of the marketplace. Sometimes the chain cuts a deal with a middleman who has acquired, say, production overruns of Lee jeans. Or it buys up ''reconditioned'' products, like Dyson vacuum cleaners that have been returned to the manufacturer (''usually just buyer's remorse,'' Martin maintains). Sometimes merchandise has to be liquidated simply because of a packaging alteration (either a new design, or even, as when Procter & Gamble bought Gillette not long ago, changes to the Universal Product Code numbers). Another recent example involved a few hundred thousand lampshades, made by a firm called Alsy Lighting, and intended for sale at places like Target and Bed Bath & Beyond, at retail prices in the $9 to $20 range; those stores were shifting their mix of product styles, so the shades ended up at Big Lots, priced between $3 and $7. 
 While this makes for an adventurous business model, it would seem to create a frustrating shopping experience. The chain advertises specific deals, but of course those deals are always short-term: the closeout offerings change constantly, and if you show up looking for a bike or a pair of jeans, you're unlikely to be satisfied with a lampshade, no matter what the price. But according to Martin, about 80 percent of Big Lots shoppers show up with no shopping list at all; they are just browsing for bargains. Many, he adds, consider themselves ''treasure hunters.''
 It makes sense, then, that Big Lots does not play down the notion that it specializes in merchandise that basically needs to be discarded for one reason or another. Signs in the store suggest that a ''closeout'' is an exciting thing to have access to. And a television ad for the chain shows a pair of ''bargain shoppers'' browsing, and one marvels: ''You know what? These are only 18 bucks, they're usually 32.'' You can't see what ''these'' are, but it doesn't really matter. Big Lots doesn't sell products; it sells bargains.
 While the specific products coming into the stores vary, Martin says, Big Lots doesn't worry too much about always having something to sell -- whether the economy is booming or flailing. ''There are always misses,'' he observes. And presumably, there are always shoppers willing to believe that those misses might actually be treasures. If supply and demand are mismatched on the first try, it's inevitable that there will be another try, and then another, until a match is made. This is how the marketplace converts, say, a lampshade from a must-liquidate style in one context to a must-have bargain in another. All of which, of course, means that the existence of Big Lots is not evidence of the marketplace's failures but of its efficiency.

HEADLINE: A Century Later, The Stoop Persists In a New Form

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY. 
E-mail: streetscapes@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE decay and housing abandonment of Harlem beginning in the 1960's left broken-tooth gaps all over, like a London neighborhood hit by scattered bombs in a Luftwaffe raid. But most of the area has rebounded with new construction, including 128th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues. 
 Here, a handful of empty lots have been filled with what look like new high-stoop row houses. But they're different from the brownstones of the 19th century -- and it's not just the stone. 
Construction on West 128th Street took off in the 1880's and 1890's, including the row of brick and brownstone houses built around 1891 at Nos. 25 through 35. Of these, Nos. 31, 33 and 35 remain. 
 The high-stoop solution for the row house achieved dominance in the 1850's, to accommodate an entrance to the kitchen and service areas a little below grade and another entrance to the entertaining rooms, well above street level. Deliveries and servants had the most direct path inside, whereas owners and guests had to climb a flight of stairs outside, but this counterintuitive architectural solution was not seriously questioned.
 The persistence of the stoop in the 19th century is something of a mystery to historians. By the turn of the century, row-house builders had shifted to grade-level entrances, so why didn't householders demand that solution decades earlier?
 The early residents of this block of West 128th were people like Joseph A. Britton, who lived at No. 6, an investigator who infiltrated gambling dens for Anthony Comstock's Society for the Suppression of Vice. At one point, he supervised a force of 14 undercover agents. 
 The houses on West 128th were not crowded: Mr. Britton lived there with only his wife. 
 The black migration that swept through Harlem after the turn of the century repopulated the houses with working-class families, and the 1930 census yields a revealing economic picture of the changes overtaking the street. One white family remained on the block, at No. 8, in a house valued at $10,000. The house at No. 35 was occupied by Alphonse Black, 35, an African-American auto mechanic, and his family of five -- they rented it for $80 a month.
 Next door, No. 33 was divided among four black families -- 15 people in all, paying a total of $127 a month. More tenants meant more rent for the landlord.
 As Harlem went into a downward slide, many buildings were demolished, wore out into empty shells or, worse, became havens for drug dealers and other criminals. 
 Although spring grass now sprouts where houses once stood at Nos. 25 through 29, there are few vacant lots left on West 128th Street. Eight have been filled with handsome new row houses, with high stoops, trim cornices, attractive variegated orange brick and projecting oriel windows on the main floor. 
 But actually there is no main floor -- each building is three apartments; those on the upper two floors are reached by an old-style exterior stoop. In fact, it's not even a row, at least in the old sense. Although the eight new buildings are essentially identical, they are sprinkled along both sides of the street, at Nos. 28, 28A, 30, 34, 58, 79, 81 and 83 West 128th. Call it a row for a deconstructed age.
 David Danois, an architect, filed plans for the buildings in 1999 as part of a program sponsored by the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the New York City Partnership, a civic group. Vacant lots were turned over to a single developer for construction of owner-occupied buildings that would help stabilize what were then iffy neighborhoods. 
 Mr. Danois says that each of the new row houses has an owner's duplex on the first two floors, plus two rental apartments on the upper floors, reached by the stoop. 
 Mr. Danois said he included stoops on all the buildings so that they would blend in with the rest of the neighborhood. But there are important differences between the 1890's and the 1990's: on the traditional row house, the ground-floor entrance was concealed right under the stoop. 
 But on the contemporary model, the ground-floor doorway is in the open, to one side of the stoop. This permits access by people with disabilities.
 The stoop itself makes a 90-degree turn and fits completely within the building line -- the stoops on older row houses were permitted to project beyond the lot, a privilege since withdrawn. 
 The old row houses were 60 feet from front to back (or even deeper), leading to dark interiors, a particular hardship when gas was used for illumination. But in Mr. Danois's design the apartments are no more than 50 feet deep, with correspondingly more light. 
 Michael Cummings, a police officer, has owned 28A West 128th Street for four years. ''I originally wanted a big yard and looked at the standard places where police officers go -- upstate, Long Island -- but I'd be traveling an hour or more to commute,'' he said. Living on West 128th, he said, ''I can grab a cab after work, take my kids down to the natural history museum and be home by dinner.''
 Across the street, the owner of the 1890's house at 33 West 128th, who declined to be identified, said she thinks the new buildings enhance the block, although she misses the berry bushes that grew on the vacant land they now occupy. She said she doesn't really notice going up and down her stoop, although ''it does give you exercise.'' 
 Across the street, a woman coming down the stoop at the new building at No. 28 West 128th said she also usually didn't notice the climb: ''If I had to take my laundry out, it would be a real problem, and with groceries it is a bother,'' she said, asking to be identified only as Pam. 
 She said that she and her sisters have the apartments on the upper floors of the new building. She wound up on the top floor and has to climb three flights, one flight up the stoop and two inside. ''After all,'' she said, ''I'm the youngest.''

Of the brownstone row pictured here, only No. 31, at the far left, survives. The modern stoops lead to two floor-through apartments. (Photo by MetroHistory.com)

HEADLINE: Setting a Sale Price in a Slow Market 

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST

 BODY:
AS the busy spring shopping season gets under way, listings throughout Connecticut are cluttered with winter leftovers. The inventory of available houses is up almost everywhere, suggesting that sellers who want their properties to move quickly have to come to terms with a cooling market and falling consumer confidence. 
 Buyers are beginning to emerge in the usual numbers, but compared with the heady spring markets of recent years, they are fussier and less pressured to act quickly, said Mary Ellen Vicino, senior vice president for the Greater Hartford area offices of Coldwell Banker Residential Brokerage.
Pricing a house realistically is crucial in this more-competitive market, especially for properties with obvious negatives. 
 ''You've got to be right on the button now with prices,'' said Rick Higgins, chairman and founder of the Higgins Group, a real estate brokerage based in Fairfield. ''People aren't going to overpay -- they're afraid to overpay. Before, people felt, 'Well, if we overpay, we'll be O.K. in six months.' They're used to 12, 15 percent gains. Now, it's 5 percent, 6 percent.'' 
 If buyers have the jitters, however, many sellers are still hoping to be the last on their street to sell at boom-market prices. Given the relentless competition, however, entering the market at too high a price may condemn a property to weeks, or even months, of market time, its value declining as buyer interest wanes.
 ''There's a backlog of people waiting to buy -- they're the experts, they've seen what's out there,'' Mr. Higgins said. ''Once they pass on a house, it's obviously not worth as much.'' 
 The inventory of available houses in Fairfield County is up roughly 30 percent over last year, he said, though the amounts vary markedly from town to town. For example, Darien's inventory is up about 40 percent over a year ago, while Ridgefield's is up just 8 percent.
 In some towns, the swollen inventory is partly explained by a glut of higher-end homes. In Westport, for example, 115 of the roughly 300 homes on the market earlier this month were in the $2-million-and-up range. 
 ''That's huge -- that's like a year's worth of inventory,'' said Darcy Sledge, an agent with the Westport office of Prudential Connecticut Realty. ''There's a lot of new construction sitting. Buyers in that range are being very choosy, and those houses not on an ideal site are sitting a little bit longer.'' 
 At the same time, sales have slowed considerably relative to last year, although many agents said properties have begun to move more briskly in the past few weeks.
 A sampling of town statistics compiled by Ms. Sledge showed that as of March 30, sales of single-family homes were down about 40 percent for the year in Easton and Weston, 15 percent in Norwalk, 10 percent in Westport and Wilton, and 7 percent in Fairfield. 
 The Greater Hartford Association of Realtors reported a 15 percent rise in inventory as of the end of February, with sales down about 17 percent for the year to date. New Haven County real estate agents are seeing similar numbers, according to Frank D'Ostilio, regional vice president for Coldwell Banker. 
 Prices are still up over last year, however, and multiple offers are common on well-sited houses in excellent condition.
 Such properties are moving ''just as fast and just as pricey as they have in the past,'' said Carole Cousins, an agent with Century 21 Landmark Properties in Ridgefield. Just recently, a ''bread-and-butter colonial'' -- Ms. Cousin's term for a traditional center-hall colonial -- in an established subdivision in Ridgefield sold for the asking price after multiple offers because, she said, ''the house was pristine.'' 
 ''The baths were done, the kitchen was renovated,'' she said. ''The house was immaculate.'' 
 Patty Hutchinson, an agent with Kelly Associates in Darien, tells a similar story about a fairly new colonial in ''perfect condition'' that listed at $3.5 million last month. The owners listed the house on a Thursday, received three offers during the weekend open house and sold it by Sunday.
 Several other Darien properties listed in the $3 million to $4 million range are languishing, she noted, because they are overpriced relative to the competition. 
 Robert Grant, an agent with the Higgins Group, has had to lower his expectations since putting his own home in Easton on the market a little more than a month ago. ''I thought I would hit the spring market hard and there would be tons of buyers out there,'' he said. After an initial flurry of calls, however, interest has tapered off to barely a phone call a week. 
 When Mr. Grant first listed his house -- a 4,000-square-foot colonial built in 1996 on three acres -- only two comparable properties were available in Easton. He set the price at $998,900. Since then, five more properties have been listed in that range, some of them larger or newer. Mr. Grant has lowered his price to $984,000, a level at which he believes there is a window in the market without competition. 
 Listing a house at the high end of its price range is not necessarily the way to go right now, agents said, especially if the house does not show as well as others in the same range. 
 Ms. Cousins recommends pricing a house at the point where it becomes the best house on the market at that price.
 Sellers are often blind to their own house's shortcomings, however, as was the case with the couple who recently asked Ms. Cousins to perform a market analysis of their home in Brookfield. 
 As Ms. Cousins pulled in, she noted that the house was built down low at the base of a steep driveway. High-tension wires loomed behind the property. 
 ''Inside, they had totally redone the kitchen, and they were very proud of that,'' Ms. Cousins said. But in the living room, the view of the backyard was dominated by railroad tracks at the back of the property. 
 When she later presented her analysis to the owners, she suggested that the house ought to be priced lower than other homes with the same number of bedrooms and square footage to make up for the low site, wires and railroad tracks. The owners ultimately rejected her analysis in favor of the higher price recommended by another agent. 
 ''If that house sits on the market for a year, people will say, 'Oh, it's a bad market,''' Ms. Cousins said. ''But no, the real problem is bad pricing.''

LENGTH: 1841 words

HEADLINE: Foreclosure Auctions: Bidder Beware

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM

 BODY:
A WOMAN bought a house with a swimming pool in the village of Southampton for $151,000. The transaction, which occurred after a foreclosure auction 10 years ago, took about five minutes. Today, she estimates her Hamptons summer home is worth $1.6 million. 
 In 1997, a man bought a 157-unit apartment building in Brooklyn at auction for $2.4 million. He has since been offered $25 million for it, but he thinks it is worth even more.
It is one of 10 buildings he has bought at foreclosure auctions in the last 15 years. 
 Buying real estate at foreclosure auctions is an alluring idea, particularly in New York where nearly everyone is scrambling for a deal. Nationwide interest has spawned an industry of foreclosure mavens as well as countless Web sites, infomercials, how-to books and seminars. 
 Foreclosure auctions, which occur after a lender or government agency forecloses on a parcel, building or apartment, are a judicial process in New York, meaning that they are run by the court system.
 Such auctions may have piqued the interest of novice investors anticipating a rise in interest rates and the inability of some owners to meet their financial obligations. 
 Yet while there is a tantalizing possibility of getting a deal, people who are intimately familiar with foreclosure auctions in New York -- lawyers, mortgage bankers, brokers and former auction regulars -- advise steering clear of them.
 Success is not impossible, but to even set foot in the ring you must put in hours of due diligence and overcome myriad obstacles, including competing against auctiongoers who have mastered the art of the bid.
 ''You really have sharks at these sales,'' said Bruce Bronster, a partner in the Manhattan office of Dreier L.L.P. -- his litigation group has handled more than 3,000 foreclosures. ''You're a guppy. And you're going up against very seasoned and sophisticated guys.'' 
 Auction regulars tend to be investors who pool their money and have ties to the construction business. They know the market, they do their research, and they have the capital and the ability to renovate properties sold ''as is.''
 That is a significant advantage because foreclosed properties are frequently in disrepair and the interiors can rarely be inspected before bidding. There may be lead paint, asbestos and bug or rodent infestations. Even worse, there can be title disputes.
 Some auctions become so frenzied that prices are driven above market value. Others are simply canceled.
 Winning can mean inheriting environmental liabilities and squatters. You will also have to pay 10 percent of the purchase price on the spot (with a certified check or cash) and the balance usually within 30 days, so you must secure financing in advance or you could lose your down payment. 
 ''You don't know exactly what you're getting,'' said Melissa Cohn, the president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company. ''That's the biggest risk.''
 For example, one of Ms. Cohn's clients bought a property at auction only to discover later that the owner had removed everything, from the doorknobs to the garage doors to the appliances. 
 Or consider the predicament of a man who Mr. Bronster said spent thousands of dollars to get out of a sale after buying his daughter a property that was advertised as a dwelling unit but turned out to be a basement space with no windows, kitchen or bathroom. 
 Then there was the investor who bought a condo at auction that he thought was one apartment but was actually two joined together. ''They had only bought half the space,'' said Marc Broxmeyer, a founder of Bellmarc Realty. The investor was shrewd and threatened to tie up the deal in litigation, so he eventually got the full space. (He had to pay for it, of course.) 
 ''It just goes to show you the craziness that can happen,'' Mr. Broxmeyer said. 
 Yet despite the pitfalls of foreclosure auctions, people do make money from them. 
 When a house Dorothy Somekh liked in Southampton turned out to be in contract, the broker told her about a foreclosed property that was up for auction by sealed bid. Ms. Somekh put in a bid without viewing the property because she was working and could not drive out to Long Island to see it.
 The next day she went out and fell in love with the house (even though it was boarded up) and asked her broker to tell the owner that she would make a higher offer than the winning bid. But her broker told her it was too late -- someone else had outbid her. 
 Ms. Somekh, a broker herself for Halstead Property, insisted. She offered $151,000 -- and, in a rare turn of events, got the house. Since then she has spent $150,000 to $200,000 renovating the property and thinks it could sell today for $1.6 million. 
 ''It was a really good deal,'' Ms. Somekh said. ''That's why you always have to take a chance. Don't take no for an answer.'' 
 Like Ms. Somekh, many people attempt to play by their own rules. Some try to buy not only at auction but also during the pre-foreclosure period, before a property goes to auction, by calling the owner directly.
 Isaac Hager, a developer, has bought several buildings at foreclosure auctions. He has his own renovation and construction teams and does so much research that he has managed to buy mortgages from banks before properties went to auction. 
 ''It's not easy at all,'' Mr. Hager said. 
 But the fact that some people have benefited from buying foreclosures is enough to inspire others to make a beeline for the county courthouse. 
 Marc Lawrence, a broker at the Corcoran Group, has run title searches and tipped doormen to find out about properties he is interested in. It is time-consuming, and he has yet to purchase anything. A few months ago, he bid on a property but it went above the price he and his fellow investors thought it was worth. Still, he perseveres. 
 ''In the competitive New York City marketplace, anytime you think you can get a bargain, you're going to grab it,'' he said. ''Or you're going to try.''
 Susan M. Darrow, a broker at Bellmarc, has been attending auctions in New York for two decades but has never bought anything because prices frequently rise above what she considers to be market value. About a month ago, a client of hers was interested in buying an apartment in a building in the East 60's, and one came up for auction. But it went for more than another apartment in the building that was already on the market for about $500,000. 
 ''It went for about $70,000 more than the one on the market,'' Ms. Darrow said, ''but the condition was really not good.'' 
 Before any foreclosure auction in New York, the terms of sale and the address of the property must be published once a week for four weeks in local periodicals, according to Jon B. Felice, the owner of Jon B. Felice & Associates P.C., a real estate law firm in Manhattan. So while you cannot usually get inside, you can get the address and view the exterior. There are also Web sites that publish foreclosure auction information for all five boroughs for a fee: PropertyShark.com ($129.95 a year), for example, and NYForeclosures.com ($999 a year). Both also offer helpful free tips to nonsubscribers. 
 Auctions generally take place at New York City's county courthouses. Some 70 percent of the city's foreclosure auctions occur in Brooklyn and Queens, according to PropertyShark. So if you have your heart set on buying in Manhattan, you will have even less to choose from. 
 Likewise if you want a co-op. While co-ops can be auctioned, they do not go through the courts because they are not considered ''real property'' (you own shares in the apartment corporation, not the unit itself). 
 Some experts recommend bringing certified checks in various amounts ($10,000, $5,000, $1,000) to meet the 10 percent down payment because you do not know exactly how much you will end up paying. Others prefer to bring one certified check -- at an amount they have decided on well before the auction -- because it prevents them from overbidding. 
 But all agree that due diligence is essential, though Mr. Bronster, the lawyer, pointed out that the condition of a property can change between the time you buy it and the time you close, especially if there is a disgruntled owner who destroys the place.
 It is also important to do a financial projection to make sure that the discount you are getting by buying at auction is substantial enough to make the risk worthwhile. 
 ''You have to know what liens are on the property so you know how much you're going to have to spend,'' Mr. Felice said. ''My gut tells me that you're buying at a discount in most instances of 30 to 40 percent.'' 
 That is enough to keep some investors coming back. The advantage for those who want to buy a home instead of an investment property, though, is that if you are satisfied with buying at only 10 percent below the market rate, you may be in luck because investors are looking for bigger returns, Ryan Slack, the chief executive of PropertyShark, said in an e-mail message. 
 Still, many foreclosures end up being bought at auction by the bank that holds the mortgage. These properties are known as real-estate-owned, and banks put them on the market for more than they paid at auction. 
 Jessica Davis, president of Profiles Publications, which owns NYForeclosures.com, recommends that amateurs observe at least three auctions before bidding. ''There is no reason anyone should have an unhappy auction story if they have done their homework,'' she said. 
 But plenty of people do their homework and are stymied nonetheless. 
 In 2004, a year after leaving her Wall Street job, Julia Hoagland decided to make her living by investing in real estate, some of which she wanted to buy at foreclosure auctions. She attended auctions in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan, and read through property files in the cramped basements of courthouses. 
 Still, she watched shells of apartments in Harlem go for $900,000, places that would require many thousands more to renovate. In another instance, the owner of an apartment in Brooklyn refused to let her in with an inspector and an electrician -- even though a day earlier his wife said they would be welcome. 
 ''Needless to say, I decided being a landlord isn't for me,'' said Ms. Hoagland, who became a broker with the Corcoran Group instead. ''You basically have to close your eyes and jump off and hope there's water in the pool.''

Two Words To the Wise: Due Diligence
 EXPERTS in foreclosure auctions suggest that prospective bidders do their homework before participating in their first auction.
 Pay to have a title report run on the property to learn about its history and about any outstanding liens. 
 Visit the property, and glean information from neighbors, doormen and the owner, if possible. 
 Go to the county clerk's office, and check any claims involving the property. 
 Call the foreclosing lawyers, who must adhere to confidentiality rules but may be able to tell you if a property will actually be auctioned off or if the owner has suddenly filed for bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: There Is No Wrong Side of the Tracks

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
THE seemingly jet-fueled pace at which homes have sold and values have appreciated has slowed, market experts say. But there has been no easing off in demand for housing with good access to mass transit, they add.
 Statewide, buying activity is running 14 percent behind last year, while the inventory of unsold homes on the market is 61 percent higher than a year ago, according to a market report recently issued to brokers.
In Randolph, Morris County, according to the report from the Otteau Appraisal Group, based in East Brunswick, the market cooled to the point where a six-month supply of available houses has built up. Randolph is an attractive and well-to-do community, noted Jeffrey Otteau, president of the company that analyzes market statistics for brokers, but it lacks a train station. 
 Meanwhile, in towns with direct train service to Manhattan like Montclair, Summit and Westfield, the inventory of homes on the market remains tight. Montclair has a two-month supply or less, according to the report. That level is the same as was reported two years ago.
 Anecdotal evidence from brokers also indicates that housing near train stations in redeveloped urban centers is among the hottest type of property available right now. That would include developments at sites designated under the New Jersey Transit Village initiative -- downtown South Orange, for example -- and others where developers are simply offering proximity to mass transit as an amenity. Hoboken is a prime instance of the latter. 
 ''People want that short commute,'' said Ronnie Laiken, president and chief operating officer of Coldwell Banker in New Jersey and Rockland County, N.Y. ''It's a point of value,'' she said, ''highly desired by many, many people.
 ''So many families have both spouses working,'' she continued, ''and they want to cut down on their time away from home, getting to and from work. A lot of the buildings in Jersey City, Weehawken, the Union area, people are looking at the homes, and saying 'Wow! This is really close to the train!' -- and places are selling out right away.''
 The average commute in the state is 30 minutes long, according to New Jersey Future, an environmental group that keeps a watch on congestion and auto pollution. That is longer than in every state but New York and Maryland.
 Commuter frustrations have fueled a turnaround in public attitudes, Mr. Otteau said. Living near a train station, which used to be considered a drawback, is now considered a very attractive feature. 
 Over the past five years, the state has established 16 sites within a mile radius of local train stations as Transit Villages in connection with its ''smart growth'' initiative. The most recent announcement added Jersey City and New Brunswick to the program.
 Aimed at helping to curb sprawl, and at encouraging growth in core cities where infrastructure already exists, the Transit Village program provides grants and planning assistance to projects that show promise of creating walkable self-contained neighborhoods.
 The projects are required to be ''pedestrian friendly'' and to employ features like extra-wide sidewalks, off-street parking and small ''pocket'' parks to foster foot traffic, according to the state's guidelines. 
 Brokers and sales agents say that condominiums situated where people can walk from home to shops and the train -- including those in the Transit Village in downtown Morristown, now under construction, and on Hoboken's west side in the vicinity of the light rail station -- are extremely popular, with people putting their names on waiting lists to buy and paying the asking price without the kind of haggling that has resurfaced recently in suburban negotiations.
 Developers leapt on the trend early, and transit-oriented development continues to proliferate all over the state.
 Right now, opposite the station at Pine and Bay Streets in Montclair, which has eight train stations, a developer, the Lincoln Property Company, is proposing to build a 165-unit building with two courtyards, a swimming pool, a day-care center, covered parking and a commuter waiting area.
 The Montclair project was designed by DMR Architects of Hasbrouck Heights, which also recently worked on plans for the ambitious redevelopment of a 31-acre former airplane factory site in Wood-Ridge into a new neighborhood centered around a new train station.
 In New Brunswick, the developer Edgewood Properties recently began construction of Fulton Square, a gated community of 209 town homes and single-floor apartments on a 13-acre site about a mile from the downtown train station. A ''trolley jitney'' will transport commuters back and forth from the station, which offers both Amtrak service and New Jersey Transit service to Newark with PATH train connections to Manhattan. The plan is that the trolley would ultimately be run by the homeowners association.
 ''We're attracting a lot of commuters who work in the city,'' said a sales representative, Madeleine Jabloner. ''They want to take advantage of the trolley. They know what a headache it is to park.'' She said Fulton Square units are nearly half sold, although construction just began last month, and the first homes will not be available until late fall.
 The same developer is working on a new town center development with 265 housing units that will go up next to the train station in Somerville, and it is a partner on a condominium development in Cherry Hill that will offer trolley service to the local station.
 In addition, Edgewood is pursuing a plan to develop a Transit Village in Piscataway, where the company is based.
 Jack Morris, president of Edgewood, said he has become a big believer in such projects. ''If a project is planned with 700 residents, and 50 percent of them use mass transit, that's 350 cars off the road,'' he said. ''That improves traffic congestion and air quality. It contributes to the quality of life.''
 A nonprofit developer, Hands Inc., based in Orange, is at work on revitalizing the area around the Highland Avenue train station on Orange's border with West Orange into an arts district.
 Hundreds of condos are under construction in former hat factory buildings near the station, and Hands recently introduced a plan to develop arts studio space, shopping and artists' live-work space in what is known as the Valley neighborhood around the station.

HEADLINE: To Dig and Plant, but Not in a Hurry

BYLINE: By BRENDAN I. KOERNER

 BODY:
AGRICULTURE is an increasingly dicey career choice for the Amish of northeastern Ohio. ''You can't make a living on the farming anymore,'' said Eli Miller, an Amish resident of Kidron, Ohio. ''There's more money in the furniture shops.''
 There's also more money in Mr. Miller's chosen profession, assembling nonelectric gadgets for Lehman's, a company in Kidron that calls itself ''the world's largest purveyor of historical technology.'' 
Among Mr. Miller's contributions to Lehman's extensive catalog, few are more popular than the Old-Fashioned Corn Planter, a favorite among consumers who romanticize Amish simplicity.
 The corn planter resembles a divining rod, except that there is a metal box, called the hopper, bolted to one prong. A user presses the planter's trowel-like tip into the soil, then squeezes the handles together. This action forces back a slide mechanism at the base of the hopper, uncovering a small hole; at this point, gravity takes over, and a few seeds (which don't have to be corn) plop to earth. 
 Emptying the hopper of its one-and-a-half-pound payload is laborious and time-consuming -- but, of course, the minimalism is exactly the point. 
 Lehman's has offered the corn planters ''on and off as long as I remember,'' said Galen Lehman, the company's president; its catalog also includes products like kerosene-powered refrigerators and one-legged milking stools. Until six years ago, the corn planters were made by a local artisan who, like Mr. Miller, had realized that the community's economic future lay in crafts, not cream. When he retired, however, his son did the math and concluded that the profit margin on the corn planter was too measly to justify continued production.
 Rather than drop the corn planter from Lehman's lineup, Mr. Lehman asked Mr. Miller, the head of the company's shop, to take over the product's assembly. Mr. Miller learned from the retiring artisan the secrets of corn-planter construction, like how to rivet the steel spade onto the bottom. 
 A few changes were also made to the original design, to maximize the product's rustic charm -- the prongs, for example, are now painted ''gardener green'' instead of bright orange.
 ''I usually build 50 at a time,'' Mr. Miller said. ''I'd basically say, with waiting for the paint to dry and everything, it's two and a half days at least before I can get them in boxes ready to ship.'' He doesn't test every planter, though he will select a few at random and check to make sure the hopper's slide pulls back in a fluid motion.
 Mr. Lehman said he had no concern that he would be ''slaughtered by Wal-Mart'' in the manual corn-planter market, contending that the relatively low demand was unlikely to spur the retailing Goliath to offer a version. He estimated that his company last year sold about 200 of the planters, priced at $49.95, exclusively through its Web site (lehmans.com), catalog and store in Kidron. 
 That sales figure qualifies the product as a solid performer by Lehman's standards. Mr. Lehman says the planter has found favor among gardeners who idealize the Amish, and among elderly people who can no longer bend down to sow seeds. The planter has not, however, sold well among the dwindling population of Amish farmers.
 ''A farmer,'' Mr. Lehman said, ''is going to have a horse-drawn implement.'' Far more popular among this demographic are products like Lehman's kerosene-powered egg incubator. 
 No matter how much they admire Amish ways, consumers from the world of television and automobiles are unlikely to start raising their own chickens.

HEADLINE: First, Tame That Envy. Then Give Thanks.

BYLINE: By BEN STEIN. 
Ben Stein is a lawyer, writer, actor and economist. E-mail: ebiz@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I RECENTLY received an e-mail message from someone who has been a close friend for almost 45 years. He works selling exotic cars to very wealthy people in a large Northeastern city. He told me that he feels a certain envy toward his clients, many of whom are billionaires. 
 ''I don't really begrudge the guys who made it themselves,'' he said, ''but I go crazy about the ones who just inherited it, who were from the lucky sperm club.''
It set my little brain racing. In today's America, so many stories are about fantastically rich young men and women, or even middle-aged men and women, who put on their pants one leg at a time just like me, but who are rich enough to own a professional sports team. And then there are those who dropped out of college but now own hotels and casinos and private jets. It's enough to make you wonder what went so wrong in your own life that you have to worry about your MasterCard bill. 
 Now, I can and will offer investment counsel and complaints about executive behavior for a good long time. But I think I can offer the greatest possible value to readers right now by saying a few words about envy and how to get past it and move on to success.
 Years ago, I went to a 12-step program on Point Dume, a lovely area in Malibu, Calif. At the time, I was making a modest living and was petrified about money many nights. I would walk my magnificent German short-haired pointer, Trixie, near the homes of fabulously wealthy stars and moguls and then return to my shabby rented cottage. 
 At the meeting, I complained about the maddening truth that so many people near me on Point Dume had so much more money than I did, and a smart woman named Jennie said: ''Instead of thinking about what you don't have, think about what you have. You have the handsomest son on the planet. You have the perfect dog. Concentrate on those. When you are tempted to feel envy, remember that envy is as bad as strychnine for you. Make a list of what you do have that is good in your life, and then the envy will lift.''
 I have been doing that for about 18 years now, and it has worked well. So to stave off envy as I read about three young financial whizzes who control a professional sports team, I made a list of what I have that I feel truly grateful for:
 My wife, the world's most kind-hearted and forgiving human, the absolute model of what a human being should be.
 Excellent health -- well beyond what I deserve, considering how unhealthy much of my life has been.
 The most varied and interesting career of anyone I know, that I would not trade for anyone else's career, not even George Clooney's or that of any billionaire hedge fund trader. (I loathe uncertainty.)
 Devoted friends, a wise and considerate sister and a stupendously capable agent.
 Devoted parents, now in eternity, who would do anything for me.
 Total strangers in our military who offer up their lives for me in Iraq and Afghanistan.
 These are all great parts of my life. But as the Bible says, ''A feast is made for laughter and wine maketh merry, but money answereth all things.'' And it's true. I am happier if I have a few coins jingling in my pockets than when I don't. So I offered some thanks about money, too:
 For the people at Dimensional Funds Advisors in Santa Monica, Calif., who run the most amazingly successful, low-cost, unmanaged but somehow deep-value index funds I have ever found. They may yet save me from my spendthrift folly and give me security in my old age.
 For Phil DeMuth, my co-author and financial adviser, who put me into these funds. 
 For TIAA-CREF, the financial services group that sold my parents low-cost variable annuities that paid off like the Powerball grand prize for them and for my sister and me. 
 For my man at Merrill Lynch, Kevin Hanley, who takes it well when I call to yell at him for tiny mistakes and who put me into Vanguard Total Stock Market VIPERs, a large jewel in my portfolio. 
 For William Danoff, who guided my savings at the Contrafund at Fidelity Investments, and has surprised me for years with his prowess at making my money grow.
 For Warren Buffett, who did so well for me from about 1978 to about 1997, though his stock, Berkshire Hathaway, has basically treaded water ever since. (I am sure he'll someday give us back the $40 billion in cash that the company has accumulated over the years.) 
 For the family of Frank and Charles Hathaway, no relation at all to Berkshire Hathaway except in their investment genius and integrity, which has done so beautifully at managing Laaco Ltd., a microcap real estate, leisure and personal storage company that has redeemed some of the multitude of terrible investment decisions I have made. 
 For Peter Morton, one of the founders of the Hard Rock Cafe, who let me invest in that company long ago and allowed me to do well with them to the point of unbelievability.
 But above all, to the whole Wall Street, ''people's capitalism'' model. 
 Because we little people are allowed to invest in the nation's growth, we can become big people. We no longer have to save under a mattress or in a bank. We no longer have to manage our money actively by buying and running a farm or an apartment building. Instead, we can flick a few buttons on a computer or make a call, and all the resources of the nation's best and brightest are at our command to let us hitch our wagons to the capitalist star. 
 IN the last 70 years or so, for the first time in history, the little guy has been able to invest with some assurance that he is not being ripped off, that he is being told the full story and that if his investment does well, he will reap the rewards, or at least a lot of them. (Don't let the hedge-fund hoopla fool you. By and large, they are not outperforming funds open to the little guy at vastly lower cost.)
 Yes, there will be some rip-offs. There is too much money floating around and too much temptation for the system to be anything like tamperproof. But in general, that much-maligned Wall Street makes it possible for anyone with some savings, some sense and some discipline to have the engine of capitalism anywhere in the world roar for him like my Cadillac STS-V. Wall Street, for all its faults, makes it possible for any of us, like the fictional television character George Jefferson, to finally get a piece of the pie.
 Anyway, this was my gratitude list, or at least a small part of it. You can have a list, too, though yours may well be totally different from mine. Viewed this way, we're all in the lucky sperm club, and it's a great day. It may change tomorrow, but as someone a lot better looking than I am said in the best movie ever made, ''Tomorrow is another day.''

HEADLINE: A Portfolio Is True To Its Convictions

BYLINE: By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
HOW much is the courage of one's convictions worth? In the case of the Gartmore International Growth fund, the answer seems to be about 15 percentage points.
 That's the amount by which the fund beat its peer group in the 12 months through March. Its total return of 41.44 percent placed it first among 585 diversified funds tracked by Morningstar that specialize in shares of large foreign companies; the average return in the group was 26.18 percent.
Gartmore International Growth has not always had remarkable returns. After its introduction in 2000, the fund fared a bit better than average one year, a bit worse the next. But almost two years ago, Gartmore, a British subsidiary of the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company in Columbus, Ohio, overhauled the fund. First the manager was replaced, then the philosophy.
 The biggest change was to drastically reduce the size of the portfolio to a handful of select stocks. If you ever wondered how the manager of a 400-stock fund decides to include stock No. 393, so did Brian O'Neill and Ben Walker, the team selected in the summer of 2004 to run the Gartmore fund. 
 Their strategy is to hold 50 to 60 stocks -- down from roughly 100 -- that fit a handful of investment themes distilled from their reading of economies, industries and markets.
 ''A lot of portfolios are too diversified,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''There is no conviction in them.''
 When funds have few holdings, however, some analysts warn investors to expect more volatility, since the performance of individual stocks has a greater impact on such portfolios. But the managers of the Gartmore fund say they are satisfied that the benefits of a concentrated portfolio outweigh the risks of increased volatility. 
 ''You're making life a lot easier for yourself once you start thinking with that mind-set,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''If you run a higher-conviction portfolio, you'll be rewarded.''
 The managers decided not to be slaves to a benchmark. Managers of many funds are forbidden from straying too far from the composition of the index against which their performance is measured. Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Walker, however, are encouraged to generate maximum absolute returns. 
 ''We've got risk parameters,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''We have to have a benchmark, but we don't pay much attention to it.'' The benchmark they all but ignore is the Morgan Stanley Capital International World ex-U.S. Index. 
 The fund's investment process sounds simple, the way Mr. O'Neill describes it. ''We search for ideas, then find the best place in the world, except the United States, to implement those ideas,'' he said.
 That is done by consulting Gartmore's analysts and fund managers who specialize in various countries and industries. ''We may start off with an idea in one country,'' he said, ''and by the time we discuss it we may decide we shouldn't be playing it there but we should be in another country.''
 For example, he said that he and his colleagues were especially interested in one idea: steel tubes. The oil industry consumes these voraciously, and with the world's appetite for oil so strong, the managers surmised that there was good money to be made in supplying the tubes.
 They found three companies in this niche worthy of consideration: Tenaris in Argentina, its French counterpart Vallourec and Sumitomo Metal in Japan.
 ''At any point we may be playing one or more of those stocks,'' Mr. O'Neill said. Right now, the fund owns Tenaris, which the managers decided was trading at the right price after a dip in valuations in emerging markets, but neither of the other two.
 But that could change at a moment's notice. One hallmark of the fund is its high turnover. According to Morningstar, the average turnover for funds of this type is 75 percent a year. At Gartmore, turnover is 250 percent a year. 
 There are no core holdings as such. Each stock in the portfolio has to earn its keep continually, and no weak performer is permitted to stay. ''If you're only running a 60-stock portfolio, the ideas that don't work have to be jettisoned quickly,'' Mr. O'Neill said.
 The fund's approach draws mixed opinions from analysts. Gregg Wolper, a senior fund analyst at Morningstar, admires the concentration in the portfolio and even invoked Mr. O'Neill's favorite expression.
 ''You like to see conviction in the managers,'' Mr. Wolper said. It is all for the better, he added, ''if they like stocks and are willing to take big positions.'' 
 ''You don't want it to be too risky, putting too much money in a few names,'' he said, but he pointed out that the Gartmore fund limits risk by owning stocks in fairly equal dollar amounts. No holding accounts for more than 3 percent of the fund's $21 million in assets and Mr. Wolper said that this showed that ''they're trying to limit the potential risk inherent in a more compact portfolio.''
 But Jeff Tjornehoj, a research analyst who follows international funds for Lipper, is not so sure that the risk is worth the ride. ''I would consider this to be a relatively volatile performer,'' he said.
 ''You really have to understand what kind of fund this is before you go chasing those returns,'' he warned. ''It's the kind of fund that can make you feel brilliant or regretful depending on when you get in.''
 He likened its performance to that of ''a basketball player who likes to take three-point shots.'' Yet he conceded that it is a player who is hitting a high percentage of those shots. Though the fund tends to have more risk, compared with others in its class, ''it tends also to pay off over the longer term,'' he said. 
 The analysts also differ in their view of the fund's costs. Mr. Wolper finds the annual expenses, at 1.65 percent of assets, ''not cheap, but not too high for such a small fund.'' The average for this type of fund is 1.59 percent, according to Morningstar. 
 For Mr. Tjornehoj, however, the expense level is ''a little steep'' And he is not thrilled about the 5.75 percent front-end load, or sales charge, either, and he questioned why an investor who chooses the fund for himself should have to pay it. 
 ''If you're paying a load, what you should be paying for is financial advice,'' he said. ''It should not be an admission ticket into a portfolio.'' 
 Those who buy the fund's shares will be investing in several companies that, like the fund itself not long ago, are undergoing an overhaul. These include Rolls-Royce, the British maker of jet engines; Commerzbank of Germany; and Hynix Semiconductor, a South Korean chip maker.
 Rolls-Royce ''over the last two years is suddenly getting its act together,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''It's making the money that G.E. has been making for the last 20 years,'' he added, comparing Rolls-Royce to one of its main rivals, General Electric. Commerzbank has similarly ''resuscitated itself'' and represents a bet on the German real estate market, he said.
 Mr. O'Neill described Hynix as ''a recovery stock that has been very kind to us.'' The company avoided bankruptcy four years ago after receiving cash infusions from government-owned companies. 
 Other holdings include Corus, a British-Dutch steelmaker; CSL, an Australian pharmaceutical company that produces a vaccine that may be used to combat avian flu; the German utility RWE; and the Japanese property developer Mitsui Fudosan.
 With so few holdings in a world of so many stocks, what is not in the fund counts for almost as much as what is, Mr. O'Neill said.
 ''There are awhole lot of things we don't want to own,'' he said. If consumers are not opening their wallets, for instance, the fund drops the stocks of companies that rely on consumer spending, despite the sheer size of that segment. 
 That way, not only do areas of interest receive focused attention, but no effort is wasted. ''If we're not interested, we forget it,'' Mr. O'Neill said.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk; MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 1329 words

HEADLINE: An Extraordinary Quarter, but Why?

BYLINE: By PAUL J. LIM

 BODY:
IN the first quarter of 2006, nearly every stock fund category worked out well for investors -- though nothing worked out quite the way the markets had expected.
 Small-company stocks, for instance, did not cede leadership to the blue chips, as many strategists had predicted. And speculation wasn't wrung out of the market. Instead, investors poured money into risky emerging-market stock funds, many of which had double-digit gains in the quarter.
Still, most investors weren't complaining. How could they? The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 4.2 percent in the quarter, nearly matching its total return for all of 2005. Not only was this the best first quarter for domestic equities since 1999, but it also showed the growing ranks of skeptics that this aging bull can still run. 
 The average general domestic equity fund returned 6.2 percent in the quarter, according to Morningstar, the mutual fund tracker. If you count all domestic stock portfolios, including sector funds, the average was 6.4 percent. That compares with a 2.2 percent gain in the fourth quarter of 2005. 
 ''Funny, there was all this talk about being in a period of generally low returns,'' said Ernest M. Ankrim, chief investment strategist at the Russell Investment Group in Tacoma, Wash. ''In reality, this was about as good as it's going to get.''
 Actually, it was even better for foreign stock portfolios, which soared 10.3 percent, on average, in the quarter, thanks to another huge rally in emerging-market stocks. The average diversified emerging-market fund rose 12.3 percent, while the average Latin American fund soared 17.4 percent. Over the last 12 months, Latin American portfolios climbed by a staggering 77.5 percent.
 Not everyone profited in the quarter. Those who bet on a drop in stock prices, for instance, by investing in so-called bear-market funds, saw them fall 1.8 percent in value, on average. 
 To be sure, this was a tiny group. But many bond fund investors were also disappointed, as long-term interest rates finally began to tick up on inflation fears.
 As the yield on 10-year Treasury notes climbed to 4.85 percent on March 31, from 4.39 percent at the start of the quarter, the value of older bonds in fixed-income portfolios fell. That led to average losses of 3.5 percent in long-term government bond funds. Intermediate-term government bond funds also fell, by 0.6 percent, as did inflation-protected bond funds, down 2.2 percent.
 Russel Kinnel, director of mutual fund research at Morningstar, said, ''The rise in the long end of the curve presents bond investors with a difficult choice'' for the remainder of the year. 
 If long-term bond yields are rising because of real concerns about the health of the economy, it could mean that now is a decent time to lock in rates by sticking with long-term Treasuries, he said.
 On the other hand, if the economy is just fine, it makes no sense to invest in long-term bonds when shorter-term debt is paying roughly the same yield.
 Of course, predicting the direction of interest rates is a futile endeavor -- much like forecasting short-term moves in the stock market. Heading into the year, many strategists -- in fact, a vast majority -- predicted that shares of large, blue-chip companies would at long last outperform small-company stocks. 
 After more than five years of leading the market, small stocks slowed down a bit last year. The S.& P. 500 actually beat the Russell 2000 index of small shares by a hair in 2005: 4.9 percent versus 4.6 percent. 
 But in the first quarter of this year, small-cap funds regained their momentum and went on a tear. The average value-oriented small-company stock fund posted a gain of 10.9 percent, while the average small-cap growth fund jumped 12.7 percent. By comparison, the average large-cap growth fund gained only 3.8 percent.
 A recent survey of investment managers by the Russell Investment Group found that most were again forecasting a large-cap rally. In fact, 70 percent of those surveyed said they were bullish on large-cap growth stocks, while only 9 percent said they were bearish on them. ''I don't know how long I'll have to say this,'' Mr. Ankrim said, ''but large caps look attractive relative to small caps, even though small caps keep winning.'' 
 There are a couple of possible explanations for the resilience of small stocks. For starters, corporate earnings have continued to grow faster than expected, and small-company earnings have been growing faster lately than large-cap profits.
 Moreover, in January, there was a growing sense in the market that the Federal Reserve might be done or almost done raising short-term interest rates -- a climb that began in June 2004.
 Because conventional wisdom says stocks should do well once the Fed stops raising rates, equities -- especially speculative ones -- took off. This would explain the 9 percent jump in the Russell 2000 in the first month of the year.
 Of course, conventional wisdom has changed somewhat, and many on Wall Street now think that the Fed, under its new chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, may raise rates at least two more times. Two quarter-point increases would mean that the federal funds rate, which the Fed raised to 4.75 percent in March, would be at 5.25 percent by the summer. If the Fed goes further than that, ''the market will probably throw up on itself,'' said Jonathan Golub, a domestic equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Funds.
 MARKET strategists are already a bit concerned about the sustainability of the first-quarter gains, partly because the nation has entered the second quarter of the second year of President Bush's term. Historically, the second and third quarters of Year 2 of a presidential term are the worst periods for stock market performance.
 According to Standard & Poor's, the S.& P. 500 has registered losses of 2 percent, on average, in second quarters of second years of presidential terms, going back to 1945. Third quarters are slightly worse, with average losses of 2.2 percent.
 A number of market watchers are predicting a slowdown -- if not a correction -- in the coming months this year. ''It's been four years since we've had a 10 percent correction in stock prices,'' said Robert Doll, president and chief investment officer at Merrill Lynch Investment Managers. ''The market is looking tired.'' 
 Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab, agreed that ''we're overdue for a more-than-typical correction.'' She added that if the market ''is going to break out of its trading range, it's more likely to break out on the downside than on the upside.''
 That is why Ms. Sonders still prefers the foreign markets to domestic stocks, as do many of her peers. She currently recommends that investors' portfolios be overweight in foreign shares, particularly emerging-market stocks. She suggests that investors play it simple by sticking with diversified emerging-market stock funds rather than individual securities.
 Yet the flood of money that has already poured into emerging-market funds this year is beginning to worry some people. 
 This year through April 5, emerging-market stock mutual funds pulled in around $9.7 billion in net new money. That is a greater sum than these portfolios attracted in all of 2003, 2004 and 2005 combined. 
 ''This is a worrisome sign to us,'' said Kevin M. Cronin, head of investments at Putnam Investments in Boston. 
 Because much of this could be considered speculative money, investors could rush out of these funds the minute their performance retreats. 
 At the very least, the trendiness of the funds is likely to add a component of uncertainty and volatility to the market, which is already confused about the direction of interest rates, oil prices and inflation.
 ''If you put a gun to my head, I'd say we still could be headed for a year of high single-digit or low double-digit returns,'' Ms. Sonders said. ''But the path between now and then isn't going to be smooth.''

HEADLINE: Here's a New Idea: A Fund Cuts Its Fees

BYLINE: By J. ALEX TARQUINIO

 BODY:
INVESTORS in the Clipper Fund got a rare treat this year. A new management team took charge of the fund on Jan. 1, after promising to do something that is rather uncommon: to cut the fund's management fee.
 The managers, Christopher C. Davis and Kenneth C. Feinberg, have worked together since 1998 on two other funds -- the Selected American Shares fund and Davis New York Venture fund. Both of those funds are managed by Davis Advisors, an investment firm that was founded by Mr. Davis's father in 1969 and is based in Tucson, Ariz. The firm is known for its activist bent, and for keeping a lid on fund ownership costs to its investors. At Clipper, it has cut the fund's old 1 percent fee by more than 40 percent.
As soon as Davis Advisors took over Clipper, the firm's employees, directors and the Davis family immediately moved $50 million of their own money into the fund. This is a tradition at Davis, where they already had $2 billion of their personal money invested in the funds under their watch.
 ''Being large investors in the funds we manage orients us to think about stewardship rather than salesmanship,'' Mr. Davis said. Besides keeping fees low, he said, they consider the tax consequences and turnover costs of every trade. 
 This penny-pinching instinct is a chief reason that Morningstar named Mr. Davis and Mr. Feinberg as domestic stock fund managers of the year in 2005. (Mr. Davis's father, Shelby M. C. Davis, who is semiretired and serves as a senior investment adviser to the firm, won the award in 1996.)
 Morningstar also praised the performance of the two funds that Christopher Davis and Mr. Feinberg already managed: They handily beat the market over the last five years, despite swimming against some powerful tides. The managers favored large and megacap stocks, at a time when small and midcap stocks were in vogue. And they left a hefty dose of financial stocks in both funds, despite a common belief that such shares do not perform well during a period of rising interest rates. 
 Their investing style has minimized portfolio turnover, which can add costs for investors in the form of transaction fees and tax inefficiency; turnover at Selected American Shares and Davis New York Venture has been only in the single digits recently. Even when market volatility was much higher earlier in this decade, the turnover rate was 15 to 20 percent a year. That is relatively low for domestic stock funds, many of which have a turnover rate of 100 percent or more.
 ''We tend to buy things if we think they have a good outlook for the next five years,'' Mr. Davis said.
 This long-term horizon gives them more incentive to take a hard look at a company's corporate governance, Mr. Davis said. Davis Advisors has two research analysts whose primary responsibility is to help the firm decide on its proxy votes. 
 Even before they invest in a new stock, the team will ask the company's management to explain the minimum results below which bonus compensation for performance will not be paid to executives. The bar might be different for different industries, Mr. Davis said, but they very often find that there is no minimum requirement at all. In that case, they may still invest in a company, but Mr. Davis said they would first look at it more carefully. 
 ''There's no problem with pay for performance; what we hate is payment for mediocrity,'' Mr. Davis said. ''Usually the problem with payment isn't in the top-performing companies, the best 5 percent. The real crisis is at the 50th to the 75th percentile.''
 The two managers are also skeptical of huge stock option grants that executives receive after a stock has fallen. Mr. Feinberg cited the example of a company whose stock declines to $10 from $20 and then climbs back to $20. ''The shareholder has gotten zero return,'' Mr. Feinberg said, ''but the managers might have made tens of millions each on stock options.'' Mr. Feinberg and Mr. Davis analyze the timing of past option grants to ferret out whether management has a history of taking advantage of shareholders.
 The team's approach has paid off for shareholders in recent years. During the five years through March 31, Selected American Shares had an average annual return of 6.2 percent, compared with 6.8 percent for Davis New York Venture. During the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index returned 4 percent a year, on average.
 The managers weren't chasing fads. They owned shares of Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase in both funds when many investors worried that those two financial behemoths would be hurt by rising interest rates. Mr. Feinberg said he saw opportunity for James Dimon, J. P. Morgan's new chief executive, to improve the bank's return on equity by cutting costs and redeploying capital. J. P. Morgan has a return on equity of around 10 percent, much lower than the 19 percent at Citigroup, he said.
 ''J. P. Morgan doesn't have to get to 19 percent,'' Mr. Feinberg said. ''If they get to 15 percent that should help the stock.'' 
 Although both Citigroup and J. P. Morgan are large diversified financial services companies, Mr. Davis and Mr. Feinberg said they also saw some great values in midsize businesses in the sector. ''Financials are lobbed into a single category,'' Mr. Davis said. ''But it's absurd to lump a California savings and loan with a global insurance company and a Midwest auto finance company.''
 For instance, they both say they like Golden West Financial, which is based in Oakland, Calif., and is the holding company for World Savings Bank, a large savings and loan. Golden West specializes in adjustable-rate mortgages. Although the company has been public for 37 years, it is still run by the same husband-and-wife team, Herbert and Marion Sandler.
 ''They're best in class for a whole host of reasons,'' Mr. Feinberg said. ''They watch every penny, because they know they're in a commodity business.'' He also said that Golden West used only its own appraisers, and that it kept loans on its own books, rather than selling them to larger financial institutions, which is a common practice in the mortgage industry.
 But by and large, the two managers have turned to the large-stock universe for their portfolios in recent years, because they say that's where they have often found the best bargains. For instance, they added Wal-Mart and increased their position in Microsoft in both funds last year.
 MR. DAVIS said he thought that large stocks were ripe for a comeback, because they underperformed the market for the last six years. He said that five years ago, the top 50 companies in the S.& P. 500, in terms of market capitalization, traded at a 168 percent premium to the next 450 companies, but that today the top 50 companies trade at a 5 percent discount to the rest of the index. 
 ''Of course, they aren't the same 50 companies,'' he said, adding that part of the reason the premium was so high five years ago was that some Internet companies were grossly overvalued. He said he still thought that leading global companies warranted a premium, rather than a slight discount, to second-tier companies.
 ''It's a matter of which pond you want to fish in,'' Mr. Davis said. ''The small to midcap stocks have had a great five years, so after that, I want to fish in another pond.''

HEADLINE: For a Few Tech Stars, Time for a Second Act

BYLINE: By JAMES PETHOKOUKIS

 BODY:
DURING the late 1990's technology bubble, plenty of mutual fund managers put up monster numbers, but those of Ryan Jacob, Malcolm R. Fobes III and Robert Zuccaro were amazing even by the stratospheric standards of the time. 
 Their funds gained more than 100 percent in both 1998 and 1999, according to Morningstar Inc.; they were the only actively managed domestic funds in that wild era to accomplish this back-to-back feat.
Their individual returns were staggering. The Kinetics Internet fund, managed by Mr. Jacob, gained 196 percent in 1998 and 216 percent in 1999. Berkshire Focus, run by Mr. Fobes, gained 104 percent and 143 percent. And Grand Prix A, managed by Mr. Zuccaro, was up 112 percent and 148 percent.
 When the bubble burst, the funds flamed out. ''Despite those amazing returns, by and large all those funds really did was lose money for a lot of people,'' Russel Kinnel, Morningstar's director of mutual fund research, said. ''One of the main points of owning a mutual fund is to be able to access high-quality professional management. But you are throwing that away when you buy funds like these with some manager who just happened to get lucky.'' 
 Were they just lucky, though? Seven years later -- with the stock market having rebounded -- how are those once-highflying managers faring? 
 Of the three, Mr. Jacob, 36, has come closest to proving that he wasn't a one-note tech fan, capable of high performance figures only during the greatest tech bull market ever. Or, as Mr. Kinnel put it, ''a manager with an ability to suspend disbelief in those Internet stocks more than anyone else.'' 
 Halfway though 1999, Mr. Jacob left Kinetics Internet to start the Jacob Internet fund. That fund began operations in 2000, and during each of its first five quarters lost anywhere from 7 percent to 55 percent. Over all, in that period, the fund fell 96 percent from its peak. But Mr. Jacob later managed the century feat again, gaining 101 percent in 2003. He has posted an average annual return of 47 percent during the last three years, putting the fund in the top 1 percent of all tech funds. 
 The performance ''gives me some degree of satisfaction,'' said Mr. Jacob, who recently moved to Redondo Beach, Calif., from New York City. ''When things fell apart, no one gave us a chance. It's pretty frustrating when everybody is constantly writing about your demise.'' 
 Frustrating it may have been, but it was hardly surprising that the media spotlight was fixed on Mr. Jacob. Thanks to his startling gains, he was often associated with the perceived speculative excess of the era. To try to avoid a repeat of such huge investment declines, Mr. Jacob has made some changes in his management style, such as adding some value stocks to his high-octane tech fund; he hopes that the move will decrease some of the fund's risk without sacrificing much on the upside. Mr. Jacob has also increased the fund's turnover rate. 
 ''That may seem controversial, but in a volatile sector like this, low turnover breeds complacency,'' he said. And despite his recent success, becoming complacent is not on Mr. Jacob's agenda. ''I know I have a ways to go until I can get the fund back to where it was when the Nasdaq was at 5,000,'' he said. 
 How far, exactly? More than 350 percent. 
 For Mr. Fobes, a former ''rookie of the year'' in Mutual Fund magazine, the decline was just as steep. His fund, Berkshire Focus, also fell 96 percent from its peak -- which it reached in August 2000. And if Mr. Jacob was the subject of some snide commentary among tech bears on Wall Street and in the news media, Mr. Fobes, to a lesser extent, received similar treatment. 
 Then again, when your fund's name is similar to that of one of the most successful investment vehicles ever -- and your own name is similar to one of the most famous on Wall Street -- your fund's performance is going to attract attention. But Mr. Fobes says the fund, based in San Jose, Calif., was named after the Berkshire Mountains in Massachusetts, not Berkshire Hathaway, the entity controlled by Warren E. Buffett.
 ''The only questions I ever get about the name come from reporters,'' Mr. Fobes said. ''Clearly, I am not trying to emulate Buffett or Berkshire. We're probably the polar opposite of Berkshire.''
 The differences are certainly more obvious than the similarities. Long-term investors have benefited from sticking with Mr. Buffett's Berkshire. Not so with Mr. Fobes's mutual fund. 
 ''Anyone who stuck with him deserves some sort of an award for that near-death experience,'' said Roy Weitz, publisher of FundAlarm, the mutual fund watchdog.
 During the last three years through March, the fund bounced back somewhat. Although its average annual return of 29 percent over that time is in the top fifth of tech funds as ranked by Morningstar, the five-year figure is much different: down 9 percent, annualized, putting it in the bottom tenth of such funds. Its assets are down to about $18 million, from $450 million at the fund's peak.
 Mr. Fobes, 41, is unfazed. ''I could survive with assets as low as $5 million, if I had to,'' he said. ''Maybe even lower.'' 
 Mr. Fobes, a former tech support worker at Adobe Systems with a degree in finance and economics from San Jose State, is the ultimate do-it-yourself investor. He started the fund in 1997 with some seed money from friends and family. And while he said he had learned some lessons from the fund's troubles -- such as not stubbornly sticking with stocks like Cisco Systems as they lose 90 percent of their value -- he still pursues the high-risk strategy of concentrating his tech fund on a couple dozen stocks, now including Google and Yahoo.
 But the great ride appears over for Mr. Zuccaro of Grand Prix. After the fund's big two years, it had losses in 2000 (33 percent ), 2001 (56 percent), 2002 (47 percent), 2004 (16 percent) and 2005 (4 percent), though it gained ground in 2003 (up 38 percent). Mr. Zuccaro, who started as an analyst for Value Line in 1967, shut down Grand Prix at the end of last year. Reached at his new home at Seabrook Island, S.C., he declined to comment on the fund's performance. 
 Mr. Zuccaro was outspoken, however, while he was running the fund. In 2001, he wrote the ill-timed ''Dow 30,000 by 2008: Why It's Different This Time.'' The book made the case for a ''new and powerful bull market unfolding over the years ahead.'' 
 IT'S a cheery view that Mr. Zuccaro continued to promote into 2005, when he predicted in his fund commentary for January that the current economic expansion would power the Dow Jones industrials to 30,000 by 2009, if not sooner. That call was hardly out of character. Mr. Zuccaro had a reputation for making short-term market forecasts, a practice eschewed by most fund managers.
 ''He was a creature of the moment, and that moment was the late 1990's,'' said Mr. Weitz of FundAlarm. ''It was like he was having a good time and letting everybody know it. For an older guy, you would have thought that he would have had a little more common sense.''
 Then there is the story of one of the hottest managers of a slightly earlier time, Heiko Thieme of the American Heritage Fund.
 Through good and bad years, Mr. Thieme, 62, doggedly stuck to a high-stakes strategy of investing in just a handful of stocks, like the British biotech, Senetek P.L.C. He had a fantastic run in the early 1990's: the fund soared 97 percent in 1991, 19 percent in 1992 and 41 percent in 1993. In the 12 years since, American Heritage has managed only three positive years. 
 In 1998 and 1999, the peak years of the bull market, the fund fell 61 percent and 32 percent. And at last check, the fund had a paltry $640,000 left. But the manager is still plugging away. ''We may be small in money, but we are bigger than life in ideas,'' said the ever-optimistic Mr. Thieme, currently coming up with new trading strategies for a possible hedge fund. ''If I ever write a book, it will be called 'Vision of an Optimist.' '' 
 His advice for managers like Mr. Jacob and Mr. Fobes is a Churchillian ''never give up.''
